revision.text:
In October 1937 there was a mass extermination of [[Belarus]]ian writers, artists and statespeople by [[USSR|Communist]] authorities. This event marks the peak of the [[Great Purge]] and [[Soviet repressions in Belarus|repressions]] in the [[Soviet Union|Soviet]]-controlled [[East Belarus]].
More than 100 notable persons were executed, most of them on the night of 29-30 October 1937. Their innocence was later admitted by the [[Soviet Union]] after [[Joseph Stalin]]'s death.
==History== On 7 September 1937 [[Joseph Stalin]] signed a list of persons to be judged by a Soviet Military commission. The list was also signed by [[Vyacheslav Molotov]], [[Lazar Kaganovich]], [[Klim Voroshilov]] and [[Nikolay Yezhov]]. The results of the trials related to persons from the Belarusian SSR were formulated in a different list dated 15 September 1937 and signed by Stalin, Molotov and the senior state security official [[Vladimir Tsesarsky]]. The list of people from the Belarusian SSR sentenced to execution included 103 persons, six more persons were sentenced to ten and more years of concentration camps.
The initial list was extended by the [[NKVD]] of the Belarusian SSR. People added to the list by the NKVD of Belarus are marked with an asterisk (*) in the list below. The executions took place in the [[Minsk]] [[Amerikanka|internal NKVD prison (known as the Amerikanka)]]. Journalist [[Leanid Marakou]] alleged that between 3 March 1937 and 22 May 1938, over 100,000 people fell victims of repressions by the Soviet authorities.

page.title: 1999 Baltimore Orioles – Cuban national baseball team exhibition series

revision.comment: Changed tense; added note about former diplomat comparing Baltimore Orioles match to 1936 Summer Olympics in Berlin

{{Good article}} {{Infobox multigame series | title = 1999 Baltimore Orioles – Cuban national baseball team exhibition series | bgcolor = lavender | image = Boys Playing Stickball, Havana, Cuba, 1999.jpg | caption = Boys playing [[stickball]] in [[Havana]], 1999 | teams = [[Baltimore Orioles]]
[[Cuban national baseball team]] | location1 = [[Estadio Latinoamericano]], [[Havana]], [[Cuba]] | date1 = March 28, 1999 | result1 = Orioles defeat Cuba, 3–2 | location2 = [[Oriole Park at Camden Yards]], [[Baltimore]], [[Maryland]] | date2 = May 3, 1999 | result2 = Cuba defeats Orioles, 12–6 }} The '''1999 Baltimore Orioles – Cuban national baseball team exhibition series''' consisted of two [[exhibition game]]s played between the [[Baltimore Orioles]] of [[Major League Baseball]] (MLB) and the [[Cuban national baseball team]] on March 28 and May 3, 1999. The first game took place in [[Havana]], while the second was held in [[Baltimore]]. This series marked the first time that the Cuban national team had faced a squad composed solely of major league players and the first time an MLB team played in Cuba since 1959. In the 1990s, Orioles' owner [[Peter Angelos]] lobbied the [[United States Government]] to gain permission to hold this series for three years. Various politicians, including members of the [[United States House of Representatives]], opposed the idea and attempted to block the series. Eventually, Angelos secured the approval in 1999, after a change in United States foreign policy to Cuba under [[President of the United States|President]] [[Bill Clinton]], which eased travel restrictions and increased cultural exchange. The Orioles won the first game, which was held in Havana, by a score of 3–2 in [[extra inning]]s. The Cuban national team defeated the Orioles 12–6 in the second game, which was held in Baltimore. The series introduced [[José Contreras]] to the American baseball audience; Contreras defected from Cuba in 2002 to pitch in MLB. The United States and Cuba now compete with each other and other nations in the [[World Baseball Classic]]. ==Background== The [[Cuban Revolution]] led to the overthrow of [[Fulgencio Batista]], an ally of the [[United States]], in 1959. [[Fidel Castro]] severed [[Cuba]]'s formerly strong ties with the United States. The United States soon instituted an [[United States embargo against Cuba|embargo against Cuba]], which has made it illegal for United States corporations to enter into business with Cuba. The [[Baltimore Orioles]], who were slated to hold a 1960 exhibition series against the [[Cincinnati Reds]] in Havana, moved the games to [[Miami]], [[Florida]].{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=iddaAAAAIBAJ&sjid=MmwDAAAAIBAJ&pg=5147,4597069&dq=baltimore+cuba+exhibition&hl=en|title=Orioles Move Havana Exhibitions to Miami: Cuban Sports Writers Irked Over Shift of Three-Game Series With Cincinnati|agency=[[Associated Press]]|newspaper=[[Pittsburgh Post-Gazette]]|date=March 29, 1960|accessdate=March 20, 2013}} No [[Major League Baseball]] (MLB) team had played in Cuba since March 21, 1959.{{cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/world/story/1999/03/28/orioles990328.html |title=Baltimore Orioles beat Cuba all-stars |publisher=[[CBC News]]|date=March 3, 1999|accessdate=March 15, 2013}} Castro made attempts to lure American baseball teams back to Cuba to no avail. In the 1970s, [[George McGovern]], a [[United States Senator]], pushed the idea of an exchange of MLB and [[college basketball]] teams as a way to bridge the impasse between the two governments, similar to the [[ping-pong diplomacy]] that aided [[US-China relations]]; however, this was blocked by the [[United States Department of State]].{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=aEwfAAAAIBAJ&sjid=etEEAAAAIBAJ&pg=613,3426682&dq=major-league-baseball+cuba&hl=en|agency=Associated Press|title=Baseball Diplomacy Failed Before|newspaper=[[Daytona Beach Morning Journal]]|page=7A|date=May 10, 1975|accessdate=March 16, 2013}} In the 1980s, [[Scott Armstrong (journalist)|Scott Armstrong]] attempted to convince [[Edward Bennett Williams]], then the owner of the [[Baltimore Orioles]], to play a game of Cuban All-Stars against his Orioles. Williams declined, as he had a position on an advisory board in the [[Reagan Administration]], which opposed having any business with Cuba. Armstrong discussed the idea with [[MLB Commissioner]] [[Bart Giamatti]] and [[MLB Players Association]] (MLBPA) chair [[Donald Fehr]]. Though Giamatti was interested, he died before he could pursue the idea. Fehr visited Cuba during the [[1994-95 MLB strike]], but could not secure an antitrust exemption. In 1996, [[Peter Angelos]], the new owner of the Orioles, met with Armstrong and [[Saul Landau]], who convinced him to pursue an exhibition series between his Orioles and the [[Cuban national baseball team]].{{cite news|first=David|last=Ginsburg|agency=Associated Press|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1999/may/02/sports/sp-33359 |title=Angelos 'Dominant' Force Behind Cuba-Orioles Series|newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=May 2, 1999|accessdate=March 15, 2013}} Angelos petitioned the [[United States Government]] to permit a series. [[United States House of Representatives|United States Representative]] [[Ileana Ros-Lehtinen]] wrote to the State Department, asking that the series be prevented.{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=pnYwAAAAIBAJ&sjid=BTcDAAAAIBAJ&pg=6331,9784633&dq=baltimore+cuba+exhibition&hl=en|title=Official opposes Orioles plan to visit Cuba|newspaper=Rome News-Tribune|date=April 3, 1997|accessdate=March 15, 2013|page=2-B}} The [[United States Department of the Treasury]] denied Angelos' request on the grounds that American money may not be spent in Cuba under the [[Trading with the Enemy Act of 1917]].{{cite news|url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/sun_sentinel/access/14692576.html?dids=14692576:14692576&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Apr+04%2C+1997&author=The+Associated+Press&pub=South+Florida+Sun+-+Sentinel&desc=CUBAN+EXHIBITION+DENIED&pqatl=google |title=Cuban Exhibition Denied |agency=Associated Press|newspaper=[[Sun-Sentinel]]|location=[[Fort Lauderdale, Florida]] |page=6.C|date=April 4, 1997 |accessdate=March 15, 2013}} {{subscription required|date=March 2013}} In January 1999, [[President of the United States|President]] [[Bill Clinton]] eased travel restrictions and increased cultural exchange between the United States and Cuba, leading Angelos to again seek permission to play an exhibition game in Cuba.{{cite news|url=http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=SAEC&p_theme=saec&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=0EAFE89424DF0AF7&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM |title=Orioles owner planning exhibitions with Cubans|newspaper=[[San Antonio Express-News]] |agency=Associated Press|date=January 18, 1999 |accessdate=March 15, 2013}} {{subscription required|date=March 2013}} Angelos met with [[Sandy Berger]], Clinton's [[National Security Advisor (United States)|National Security Advisor]], to discuss a potential exhibition.{{cite news|agency=Associated Press|url=http://chronicle.augusta.com/stories/1999/01/29/oth_251713.shtml |title=Angelos wants Clinton's help to save Orioles-Cuba games |newspaper=[[The Augusta Chronicle]] |date=January 29, 1999|accessdate=March 15, 2013}} [[Bud Selig]], the MLB Commissioner, allowed for the exploration of the series, though it still required the approval of MLB owners and the MLBPA.{{cite news|url=http://articles.baltimoresun.com/1999-01-10/sports/9901090010_1_league-baseball-major-league-rafael-palmeiro |first=Peter|last=Schmuck|authorlink=Peter Schmuck|title=O's-Cuba exhibition needs to fly for charity's sake |newspaper=[[The Baltimore Sun]] |date=January 10, 1999 |accessdate=March 15, 2013}} The MLBPA insisted on a second game to be held in the United States.{{cite news|first=Murray|last=Chass|authorlink=Murray Chass|date=March 15, 1999 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1999/03/15/sports/baseball-spring-training-baltimore-cuba-game-2-of-series-set-for-may-3.html |title=Baseball: Spring Training – Baltimore-Cuba; Game 2 of Series Set for May 3 |newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|accessdate=March 15, 2013}} A contingent of United States Representatives, including Ros-Lehtinen, [[Robert Menendez]], [[Dan Burton]], [[Lincoln Diaz-Balart]], and [[Rick Lazio]], lobbied Fehr to try to block the series.{{cite web|url=http://articles.philly.com/1999-02-05/sports/25502176_1_cuban-doctors-cuban-officials-cuban-people |title=Congress Calls On Fehr About O's-cuba Game |work=[[Philly.com]] |publisher=[[Philadelphia Inquirer]] |date=February 5, 1999 |accessdate=March 15, 2013}} Ongoing negotiations through March{{cite news|url=http://articles.sun-sentinel.com/1999-03-06/sports/9903060055_1_estadio-latinoamericano-cuba-s-communist-society-young-cubans |title=Baltimore Scrambles To Finalize Games With Cuba |first=Dana|last=Calvo|newspaper=Sun-Sentinel |date=March 6, 1999 |accessdate=March 15, 2013}} yielded an agreement on March 7, 1999, over the objections of the State Department.{{cite news|first=Murray|last=Chass|date=March 7, 1999 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1999/03/07/sports/baseball-deal-is-finally-worked-out-for-orioles-cuba-exhibition.html |title=Baseball; Deal Is Finally Worked Out For Orioles-Cuba Exhibition |newspaper=The New York Times |accessdate=March 15, 2013}} The proceeds of the series were a major sticking point in negotiations, as it violated the [[United States embargo against Cuba]]. Instead of going to the [[Cuban Government]], it was agreed that proceeds would fund baseball programs in Cuba. The series created a good deal of criticism, especially among the [[Cuban American]] community. MLB [[umpire (baseball)|umpire]] [[Rich Garcia]], who is of Cuban descent, opposed the series.{{cite web|url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/baseball/mlb/news/1999/03/25/cuba_package/ |title=Cuba-Orioles matchup a game of political hardball|date=March 26, 1999 |publisher=Sportsillustrated.cnn.com|accessdate=March 15, 2013}} MLB umpires filed a grievance against MLB attempting to block them from being sent to umpire the game in Cuba,{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=-LZIAAAAIBAJ&sjid=0IEMAAAAIBAJ&pg=1776,6246763&dq=baltimore+cuba+umpire&hl=en |title=Umpires strike back |newspaper=The Vindicator |location=[[Youngstown, Ohio]] |date=March 13, 1999 |page=C2 |accessdate=April 13, 2013}} and refused to officiate the game in Baltimore.{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=Z49XAAAAIBAJ&sjid=FvIDAAAAIBAJ&pg=2101,834750&dq=umpires+cuban+national+team+baltimore&hl=en |title=Umpires to strike out over Orioles-Cuba game |newspaper=[[The Spokesman-Review]] |page=C3 |location=[[Spokane, Washington]] |date=April 22, 1999 |accessdate=April 13, 2013}} The [[Cuban American National Foundation]] protested the series. Former US diplomat [[Otto Reich]] likened the baseball match in Havana to the notion of playing soccer at Auschwitz and also the 1936 Summer Olympics in Berlin, dismissing it as a propaganda ploy by the Cuban government.https://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2002/10/14/castros-shadow ==Games== ===Game one=== [[File:La Habana - Estadio Latinoamericano.jpg|right|thumb|[[Estadio Latinoamericano]] in [[Havana]] hosted the first game of the series on March 28, 1999.]] Game one took place at [[Estadio Latinoamericano]] in [[Havana, Cuba]], on March 28, 1999. Tickets were distributed by invitation only.{{cite news|url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/tampabay/access/40068901.html?dids=40068901:40068901&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Mar+27%252C+1999&author=&pub=St.+Petersburg+Times&desc=Cuba+makes+exhibition+game+by+invite+only+Series%253A+AROUND+THE+AL&pqatl=google |title=Cuba makes exhibition game by invite only Series |newspaper=[[St. Petersburg Times]]|page=5.C|date=March 27, 1999 |accessdate=March 15, 2013}} {{subscription required|date=March 2013}} Angelos, Selig, and Castro sat together in [[box seat]]s.{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/sports/orioles/daily/march99/29/os29.htm |title=Orioles Leave Cuba With a Win |newspaper=[[Washington Post]] |first=Richard|last=Justice|page=D1|date=March 29, 1999 |accessdate=March 15, 2013}} One hundred schoolchildren from the Baltimore and [[Washington, D.C.]] area also traveled to Cuba on a plane chartered by Angelos.{{cite news|url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/baseball/mlb/news/1999/03/25/orioles_cubakids/ |agency=Associated Press|title=Baltimore students join Orioles for Cuba trip |publisher=Sportsillustrated.cnn.com |date=March 25, 1999 |accessdate=March 15, 2013}} Before the game, players and [[coach (baseball)|coaches]] on both teams engated in a flag ceremony. Castro greeted the Orioles on the field, and gave his Cuban team a pep talk. Cuban baseball legend [[Conrado Marrero]] threw out the first pitch.{{cite web|url=http://www.baseballdecuba.com/newsContainer.asp?id=2205 |title=Connie Marrero Still Strong at 99 |first=Peter C. |last=Bjarkman |date=April 18, 2010 |publisher=Baseballdecuba.com |accessdate=March 15, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130921060832/http://www.baseballdecuba.com/newsContainer.asp?id=2205 |archivedate=September 21, 2013 |df= }} Orioles' [[starting pitcher]] [[Scott Erickson]] allowed one [[run (baseball)|run]] on five [[hit (baseball)|hits]] in seven [[innings pitched]]. Cuban starter [[José Ibar]] allowed a [[home run]] to [[Charles Johnson (catcher)|Charles Johnson]] and was relieved in the third inning by [[José Contreras]]. Contreras pitched eight innings without allowing a run. Orioles' [[manager (baseball)|manager]] [[Dave Miller (baseball)|Dave Miller]] brought in his [[closer (baseball)|closer]], [[Mike Timlin]], in the eighth inning. This backfired, as [[Omar Linares]] tied the game for Cuba with a [[run batted in]] [[single (baseball)|single]]. Tied after nine innings, the game went into [[extra innings]]. Cuba had two runners on base in the 10th inning, but [[Mike Fetters]] retired Cuba without allowing a run. The Orioles won the game when [[Harold Baines]] hit a single off of [[Pedro Luis Lazo]] that scored [[Will Clark]] with the go-ahead run in the top of the 11th inning. [[Jesse Orosco]] recorded the final three outs in the bottom of the 11th, as the Orioles won by a score of 3–2. ;Line score{{cite news|url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/baseball/mlb/grapefruit/scoreboards/1999/03/28/finalbox..baltimore.0344.html|title=Box Score: Baltimore Orioles at Cuba|work=CNN Sports Illustrated|date=March 28, 1999|accessdate=March 15, 2013}} {{Linescore| |Road=Baltimore Orioles|RoadAbr=BAL |R1=0|R2=2|R3=0|R4=0|R5=0|R6=0|R7=0|R8=0|R9=0|R10=0|R11=1|RR=3|RH=6|RE=0 |Home=Cuban National Team|HomeAbr=CUB |H1=0|H2=0|H3=0|H4=0|H5=0|H6=0|H7=1|H8=1|H9=0|H10=0|H11=0|HR=2|HH=10|HE=0 |WP=[[Mike Fetters]]|LP=[[Pedro Luis Lazo]]|SV=[[Jesse Orosco]] |RoadHR=[[Charles Johnson (catcher)|Charles Johnson]] |HomeHR= }} ;Box score {{col-begin}} {{col-break}} {| class="wikitable sortable plainrowheaders" |- !scope="col"|Baltimore !scope="col"|[[At bat|AB]] !scope="col"|[[Run (baseball)|R]] !scope="col"|[[Hit (baseball)|H]] !scope="col"|[[Run batted in|RBI]] |- !scope="row"|{{sortname|Brady|Anderson}}, [[Center fielder|CF]] |4 |0 |1 |0 |- !scope="row"|{{sortname|Mike|Bordick}}, [[Shortstop|SS]] |5 |0 |1 |0 |- !scope="row"|{{sortname|Will|Clark}}, [[First baseman|1B]] |3 |1 |1 |0 |- !scope="row"|{{sortname|Albert|Belle}}, [[Right fielder|RF]] |5 |0 |0 |0 |- !scope="row"|{{sortname|B. second game of the series took place at [[Oriole Park at Camden Yards]] in [[Baltimore]] on May 3, 1999. This photo depicts the stadium in 2008.]] The second game was held at [[Oriole Park at Camden Yards]] in Baltimore on May 3, 1999,{{cite news|url=http://articles.sun-sentinel.com/1999-05-03/news/9905030121_1_cuba-people-to-people-contact-people-to-people-exchanges |first1=William E.|last1=Gibson|first2=Rafael|last2=Lorente|first3=Dana|last3=Calvo|title=Cuba, Orioles Take The Field In Game Filled With Intrigue |newspaper=Sun-Sentinel|date=May 3, 1999 |accessdate=March 15, 2013}} in front of 47,940 fans. By May 3, the Orioles had a 7–17 [[win-loss record]] in the [[1999 MLB season]]. The Cuban national team, meanwhile, was stronger than during the first game, as the [[1998–99 Cuban National Series]] had concluded and players who were not available for the first game of the exhibition joined the Cuban team. A 300-person delegation accompanied the Cuban team, including members of the Cuban media, students, and retired players. MLB requested the [[Federal Aviation Administration]] clear the airspace above Camden Yards for the game, in response to an attempt by a [[Miami]]-based pilot and veteran of the [[Bay of Pigs invasion]], to drop anti-Castro [[leaflet (information)|leaflets]] over Estadio Latinoamericano during the first game.{{cite news|url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/baseball/mlb/news/1999/04/24/orioles_airspace/ |agency=Associated Press|title=MLB asks for restrictions during Cuba-Orioles game in Baltimore |date=April 24, 1999 |publisher=Sportsillustrated.cnn.com |accessdate=March 15, 2013}} The start of the game was [[rain delay|delayed]] by rain for 56 minutes. The game was further interrupted by protesters, one of whom ran onto the field during the fifth inning and had to be thrown to the ground by [[César Valdez (umpire)|César Valdez]], a Cuban umpire. Contreras started the game for Cuba, and he allowed a two-run [[double (baseball)|double]] by Baines in the first inning. Orioles' starting pitcher [[Scott Kamieniecki]], who was on the MLB [[disabled list]] at the time, allowed four runs in the second inning to give Cuba the lead. [[Norge Luis Vera]] entered the game for Cuba in the third inning and pitched {{frac|6|2|3}} innings in relief without allowing a hit, retiring 20 of the first 22 batters he faced. His hitless streak ended when he allowed a [[home run]] to [[Delino DeShields]] in the ninth inning.{{cite web|url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/baseball/mlb/ml/scoreboards/1999/05/03/recap.BAL-CUB.html|title=Exhibition Baseball Recap (Cuban All-Stars–Baltimore|work=Sports Illustrated|date=May 4, 1999|accessdate=March 26, 2013}} [[Gabe Molina]], who had made his MLB debut on May 1, allowed Cuba to score five runs in the ninth inning, including a three-run home run hit by [[Andy Morales]]. The Cuban national team defeated the Orioles 12–6. [[Danel Castro]] batted 4-for-5 for Cuba, including a two [[run batted in]] (RBI) [[triple (baseball)|triple]], and scored four runs. [[Calvin Pickering]], a [[rookie]] [[first baseman]] for the Orioles who had been promoted from the [[minor league baseball|minor leagues]] the day prior, committed three [[error (baseball)|errors]].{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/sports/orioles/daily/may99/04/os4.htm |title=Orioles Get Smoked by Cubans, 12–6|first=Richard|last=Justice|page=D1 |newspaper=Washington Post |date=May 4, 1999 |accessdate=March 15, 2013}} ;Linescore{{cite web|url=http://www.baseballprospectus.com/article.php?articleid=19801|date=March 5, 2013|title=Wezen-Ball: ==Aftermath== [[Rigoberto Herrera]], a member of the Cuban national team who had retired and accompanied the team from Cuba as a guest, defected to the United States during the visit. Though six retired players overslept the day after the game in Baltimore and missed their flight back to Cuba, no other members of the delegation defected.{{cite news|url=http://articles.sun-sentinel.com/1999-05-05/news/9905041180_1_cuban-exiles-cuban-umpire-cuban-diplomatic-mission |title=Castro Welcomes Stars Home |newspaper=Sun-Sentinel |first1=Dana|last1=Calvo|first2=Rafael|last2=Lorente|date=May 5, 1999 |accessdate=March 15, 2013}} [[File:AAAA4577 José Contreras.jpg|left|thumb|250px|[[José Contreras]] pitching for the [[Chicago White Sox]] in 2008]] To discourage defections during the exhibition in Baltimore, Cuba maintained strict security around their young players, not allowing [[agent (sports)|sports agents]] to speak with them. Though no active Cuban players defected during the trip to Baltimore, members of the Cuban national team did defect in the years following the series. [[Andy Morales]] defected in 2000.{{cite news|url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/USAToday/access/56744092.html?dids=56744092:56744092&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Jul+21%2C+2000&author=Rod+Beaton&pub=USA+TODAY&desc=One+sure+thing+is+Cuba's+Morales+will+get+offers&pqatl=google|title=One sure thing is Cuba's Morales will get offers|newspaper=[[USA Today]]|first=Rod|last=Beaton|date=July 21, 2000|accessdate=March 23, 2013}} {{subscription required|date=March 2013}} Contreras, who was considered Cuba's best pitcher, gained international fame after the series and defected from Cuba in 2002.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2002/10/11/sports/baseball-roundup-cuban-defector-wants-to-pitch-in-majors.html |title=Baseball: Roundup; Cuban Defector Wants to Pitch In Majors |newspaper=The New York Times |date=October 11, 2002 |accessdate=March 15, 2013}} [[Nelson Díaz (umpire)|Nelson Díaz]], a Cuban umpire who officiated the game in Baltimore, defected from Cuba to the United States in 2009.{{cite web|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/mlb/news/story?id=4701570 |title=Report: Top Cuban umpire Nelson Diaz defects to U.S. |agency=Associated Press |work=ESPN |publisher=ESPN Internet Ventures |date=November 30, 2009 |accessdate=April 13, 2013}} MLB and the [[Major League Umpires Association]] engaged in a dispute regarding the amount of pay owed to umpires for officiating the game that took place in Baltimore. This was one factor that led to the [[1999 Major League Umpires Association mass resignation|mass resignation]] of MLB umpires that took place on September 2, 1999.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1999/07/15/sports/baseball-umpires-threaten-to-quit-on-sept-2.html|title=Baseball; Umpires Threaten To Quit On Sept. 2|first=Murray|last=Chass|newspaper=The New York Times|date=July 15, 1999|accessdate=April 13, 2013}} In 2000, [[Syd Thrift]], the Orioles' [[general manager (baseball)|general manager]], told ''[[The Washington Times]]'' that the team had a practice of not signing players who had defected from Cuba, which he attributed to Angelos' desire to avoid doing "anything that could be interpreted as being disrespectful or ... encouraging players to defect". Investigations by Major League Baseball and the [[United States Department of Justice]] did not find evidence that the absence of Cuban players on the Orioles' roster or in its minor league system was due to discrimination.{{cite web|url=http://static.espn.go.com/mlb/s/2002/1110/1458871.html |work=ESPN.com|title=Bud passes the buck on Cuba |publisher=ESPN Internet Ventures |date=July 16, 2003|accessdate=March 15, 2013}}{{cite news|url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2001/aug/17/20010817-024844-7964r |title=Probe of Orioles finds no violations |newspaper=[[Washington Times]] |date=August 17, 2001|accessdate=March 15, 2013}} The Cuban national team next played in the United States during the [[2006 World Baseball Classic]] (WBC). President [[George W. Bush]] attempted to prevent the Cuban team from participating in the tournament, but other nations promised to withdraw if Cuba was barred.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2006/03/20/sports/sportsspecial/20chass.html?_r=0|title=Stars Are Mostly Gone, Save the One on Cuba's Flag|first=Murray|last=Chass|newspaper=The New York Times|date=March 20, 2006|accessdate=April 13, 2013}} The next American team to travel to Cuba was the [[Tampa Bay Rays]], which played an exhibition against the Cuban national team in March 2016.{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/03/21/sports/baseball/when-mlb-broke-the-ice-with-a-game-in-havana.html|title=When M.L.B. Broke the Ice With a Game in Havana|first=David|last=Waldstein|work=The New York Times|date=March 20, 2016|accessdate=March 21, 2016}} ==See also== {{Portal bar|Baseball|Cuba|United States|International relations}} *[[1999 in baseball]] *[[American Series]] *[[Cuba–United States relations]] *[[Ping-pong diplomacy]] ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} {{Baltimore Orioles}} {{DEFAULTSORT:1999 Baltimore Orioles - Cuban national baseball team exhibition series}} [[Category:International baseball competitions hosted by Cuba]] [[Category:International baseball competitions hosted by the United States]] [[Category:Baltimore Orioles]] [[Category:1999 in baseball]] [[Category:1999 in sports in Maryland]] [[Category:1999 in Cuban sport]] [[Category:Cuba national baseball team]] [[Category:Cuba–United States relations]] [[Category:Politics and sports]]

{{Nazism sidebar}}
The '''Artaman League''' ([[German language]]: '''Artamanen-Gesellschaft''') was a German [[agrarianism|agrarian]] and [[völkisch]] movement dedicated to a ''[[Blood and Soil|Blood and soil]]''–inspired ruralism. Active during the inter-war period, the League became closely linked to, and eventually absorbed by, the [[Nazi Party]].
==Etymology== The term ''Artamanen'' had been coined before the First World War by Dr. [[Willibald Hentschel]], a believer in racial purity who had founded his own group, the Mittgart Society, in 1906. The term was a [[Compound_(linguistics)|compound noun]] of ''art'' and ''manen'', [[Middle High German]] words meaning 'agriculture man', and indicating Hentschell's desire to see Germans retreat from the decadence of the city in order to return to an idyllic rural past.<ref name="Padfield37">Peter Padfield, ''Himmler: Reichs Führer-SS'', Cassell & Co, 2001, p. 37</ref>
==Origins== The Artaman League had its roots in the overall [[Lebensreform]] movement in late 19th-century and early 20th-century Germany. This movement encompassed hundreds of groups throughout Germany that were involved in various experiments tied to ecology, health, fitness, [[vegetarianism]], and [[naturism]] (''Nacktkultur''). These groups held positions across the political spectrum. The far-right groups ultimately gained a following among the Nazi Party members and their supporters. Publications by right wing Lebensreformists, which sold in the tens of thousands, argued that their practices were "the means by which the German race would regenerate itself and ultimately prevail over its neighbours and the diabolical Jews who were intent on injecting putrefying agents into the nation's blood and soil".<ref>{{cite book|last=Gordon|first=Mel|title=Voluptuous Panic: The Erotic World of Weimar Berlin|year=2006|publisher=Feral House|isbn=1-932595-11-2|pages=138–9}}</ref>
==Development== [[File:Bundesarchiv Bild 183-H1215-503-009, Walther Darré bei einer Kundgebung.jpg|thumb|left|[[Walther Darré]] speaking at a ''Reichsnährstand'' assembly under the slogan '[[Blut und Boden]]' (blood and soil) in [[Goslar]], 1937]]
Although Hentschel had developed his ideas before World War I, the Artaman League first formed in 1923.<ref name="Padfield37"/> The Artamans formed part of the [[German Youth Movement]], representing its more [[right-wing]] [[back-to-the-land]] elements.<ref>[[Heinz Höhne]], ''The Order of the Death's Head: The Story of Hitler's SS'', Penguin Books, 2000, pp. 46-47</ref> Under the leadership of [[Georg Kenstler]] they advocated [[blood and soil | blood-and-soil]] policies with a strong undercurrent of [[anti-Slavism]].<ref name="Hohne47">Höhne, ''The Order of the Death's Head'', p. 47</ref> This [[völkisch movement]] believed that the decline of the [[Aryan race]] could only be halted by encouraging people to abandon city life in favour of settling in the rural areas in the east.<ref name="Read">Anthony Read, ''The Devil's Disciples'', Pimlico, 2004, p. 159</ref> Whilst members wished to perform agricultural labour as an alternative to military service, they also saw it as part of their duty to violently oppose [[Slavs]] and to drive them out of Germany.<ref name="Snyder">Louis Leo Snyder, ''Encyclopedia of the Third Reich'', Wordsworth, 1998, p. 12</ref> The concepts were combined in the figure of the [[Wehrbauer]], or soldier-peasant.<ref>[[Heather Pringle]], ''The Master Plan: Himmler's Scholars and the Holocaust'', p39 {{ISBN|0-7868-6886-4}}</ref> Accordingly, the League sent German youth to work on the land in [[Saxony]] and in [[East Prussia]] in an attempt to prevent these areas being settled by [[Poles]].<ref name="Read"/> To this end 2000 settlers were sent to Saxony in 1924 - both to work on farms and to serve as an anti-Slav militia.<ref name="Hohne47"/> They also gave classes on the importance of racial purity and the Nordic race, and on the corrupting influence of city living and of Jews.<ref>Heather Pringle, ''The Master Plan: Himmler's Scholars and the Holocaust'', p39-40 {{ISBN|0-7868-6886-4}}</ref>
Like many similar right-wing youth movements in Germany the Artaman League lost impetus as the Nazi Party grew. By 1927, 80% of its membership had become Nazis.<ref name="pringle40"> Heather Pringle, ''The Master Plan: Himmler's Scholars and the Holocaust'', p40 {{ISBN|0-7868-6886-4}} </ref> The League had disappeared by the early 1930s, with most of its membership having switched to the Nazis.<ref name="Snyder"/>
==Nazi links== [[File:Himmler45.jpg|thumb|left|upright|[[Heinrich Himmler]] in 1945]] As the situation deteriorated in the late 1920s, some of the Artamans were drawn deeper into politics, and engaged in a holy war against their enemies: liberals, democrats, Free-Masons and Jews.<ref name="LePage"/> Eventually many members of the Artaman League turned to National Socialism. [[Heinrich Himmler]] was an early member and held the position of ''Gauführer'' in [[Bavaria]]. Whilst a member of the League Himmler met [[Richard Walther Darré]] and the two struck up a close friendship, based largely on Darré's highly developed ideological notions of [[blood and soil]] to which Himmler was attracted.<ref name="Hohne47"/> The Artaman vision would continue to have a profound effect on Himmler who, throughout his time as [[Reichsführer-SS]], retained his early dreams of a racially pure peasantry.<ref>Höhne, ''The Order of the Death's Head'', p. 48</ref> Himmler was also close to his fellow member [[Rudolf Höss]] and would later advance him in the [[Schutzstaffel]] due in part to their history in the Artaman League.<ref>[[Richard J. Evans]], ''The Third Reich in Power'', Penguin Books, 2006, p. 84</ref> The small league was dismantled and incorporated into the Hitler Jugend in October 1934 as the Nazi youth movement gained strength.<ref name="LePage">LePage, Jean-Denis, ''The Hitler Youth, 1922-45: An Illustrated History'' (London: MacFarland, 2009), p. 17</ref>
==Legacy== The development of a number of environmentalist groups and projects in Germany with extreme right wing politics has recently gained media attention. Since the 1990s, far-right environmentalists have taken advantage of cheap farmland made available by the post-Cold War reunification of East and West Germany, establishing themselves in [[Mecklenburg]], "in an effort to reinvigorate the traditions of the Artman League".<ref name="Connolly">{{cite news|last=Connolly|first=Kate|title=German far-right extremists tap into green movement for support|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2012/apr/28/germany-far-right-green-movement|accessdate=April 29, 2012|newspaper=The Guardian|date=28 April 2012}}</ref> The state government of [[Rhineland-Palatinate]] has published a booklet titled ''Nature Conservation vs Rightwing Extremism'' in an effort to assist organic farmers who may encounter rightwing extremists. Gudrun Heinrich of the University of Rostock has published a study, ''Brown Ecologists'', in reference to both the current movement and the Nazi [[Sturmabteilung|Brownshirts]]. The politically extreme rightwing environmental magazine ''Umwelt und Aktiv'' (Environment and Active), is believed to receive support from Germany's far-right National Democratic party (NPD).<ref name="Connolly"/> ''[[Der Spiegel]]'' has covered the "organic brown fellowship" ("Braune Bio-Kameradschaft"),<ref>{{cite web|last=Pfaffinger|first=Von Christian|title=Braune Bio-Kameradschaft|url=http://www.spiegel.de/politik/deutschland/0,1518,814893,00.html|date=April 3, 2012|work=Der Spiegel|accessdate=April 29, 2012}}</ref> and ''[[Süddeutsche Zeitung]]'' has published an article on and the “infiltration [''Unterwanderung''] of organic farming by rightwing extremists,<ref>{{cite web|author1=Thiele, Von Christian |author2=Marlene Weiss |lastauthoramp=yes |title=Unterwanderung des Biolandbaus durch Rechtsextreme: Idylle in Grün-Braun|url=http://www.sueddeutsche.de/politik/unterwanderung-des-biolandbaus-durch-rechtsextreme-idylle-in-gruen-braun-1.1332321|date=April 13, 2012|work=Süddeutsche Zeitung|accessdate=April 29, 2012}}</ref> noting the lineage to Nazi doctrines of Aryan supremacy and ecological harmony.
==References== {{Reflist|2}}

An '''authorization to transport''' [ATT] is a permit issued under the [[Canadian Firearms Program]] allowing transportation of restricted and prohibited firearms in Canada. An ATT may be issued to a firearms licensee, or to a non-resident of Canada not possessing a firearms licence.<ref>[http://www.cbsa-asfc.gc.ca/publications/pub/bsf5044-eng.html#P010] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080613200414/http://www.cbsa-asfc.gc.ca/publications/pub/bsf5044-eng.html |date=2008-06-13 }}</ref> Section 19 of the Firearms Act (FA) details the various reasons for transportation which may be approved by the chief provincial firearms officer (CFO).
While not a specific requirement under the Firearms Act, ATTs issued for regular trips for up to five years are usually reserved for people who belong to an approved shooting range. Under the Firearms Act, section 67, a CFO considering a licence renewal must confirm whether a restricted firearm or prohibited handgun is being used by the licence holder for the legitimate reasons found in FA section 28. In order to prove one has a licence to permit target shooting, regular trips to the gun range or club must be made, and repeated one-time ATTs would be a waste of resources. In contrast, a gun collector under FA section 30 might transport firearms occasionally, thus a one-time ATT would make sense.
In theory, a CFO should issue an ATT to any authorized individual who provides one of the listed reasons, as long as the CFO is satisfied that the transport "will not endanger public safety". A CFO can impose a variety of conditions on an ATT, under section 58(1) of the Firearms Act. Exercise of this discretion has led to proposed litigation against the CFO in Ontario.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sunnewsnetwork.ca/sunnews/politics/archives/2013/01/20130128-153941.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-07-01 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140714172046/http://www.sunnewsnetwork.ca/sunnews/politics/archives/2013/01/20130128-153941.html |archivedate=2014-07-14 |df= }}</ref>
In order to transport a restricted or prohibited firearm it must be unloaded. It also must have a functional [[trigger lock]] and be kept in a locked opaque case. Ammunition may be carried with the firearm or separately stored, provided it is not loaded in the gun (i.e., magazines may contain ammo, but may not be loaded in the firearm).
Restricted firearms include, but are not limited to, [[handguns]]. All handguns are, at a minimum, restricted in Canada. Many handguns (common in the United States) are prohibited firearms in Canada, as their barrel length is 105 mm or less, or they are a prohibited calibre (.25 and .32).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://laws-lois.justice.gc.ca/eng/acts/C-46/page-42.html#h-37 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-07-01 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140714155318/http://laws-lois.justice.gc.ca/eng/acts/C-46/page-42.html |archivedate=2014-07-14 |df= }}</ref>
Bill C-42 amended the Firearms Act, which caused ATTs to become a condition of a licence.<ref>[http://www.rcmp-grc.gc.ca/cfp-pcaf/bulletins/bus-ent/20150619-91-eng.htm]</ref> "Authorizations to Transport become a condition of a licence for certain routine and lawful activities such as target shooting; taking a firearm home after a transfer; going to a gunsmith, gun show, a Canadian port of exit; or a peace officer or a Chief Firearms Officer (CFO) for verification, registration or disposal". Effective September 2, 2015, these changes to the Firearms Act came into force meaning an ATT became a condition of a licence for the foregoing routine and lawful activities. In other words, an ATT is automatically included into any valid RPAL licence.

A '''BIGOT list''' (or '''bigot list''') is a list of personnel possessing appropriate [[security clearance]] and who are cleared to know details of a particular operation, or other sensitive information.<ref name="jargon">{{cite book| last = Green| first = Jonathon| title = Dictionary of Jargon| year = 1987| publisher = Routledge| isbn = 0-7100-9919-3| page = 55 }}</ref><ref name="spybook">{{cite book| author2 = Thomas B. Allen| last = Polmar| first = Norman| title = Spy Book: The Encyclopedia of Espionage| year = 1998| publisher = Random House| isbn = 0-375-70249-0| page = 66 }}</ref>
==Etymology== There are two slightly differing, but related, etymologies for the origin of the term:
One common etymology is that BIGOT is a reversal of the codewords "TO GIB", meaning "To [[Gibraltar]]". The context of this etymology is the Allied [[North African Campaign|invasion of North Africa]] in November 1942: "TO GIB" was stamped on the orders of military and intelligence staff travelling from Britain to North Africa to prepare for the operation.<ref name="natgeo">{{cite journal |url=http://ngm.nationalgeographic.com/ngm/0206/feature1/ |title=Untold Stories of D-Day |first=Thomas B. |last=Allen |journal=[[National Geographic (magazine)|National Geographic]] |date=June 2002}}</ref> The majority of personnel made a dangerous journey by sea, through areas patrolled by German U-boats, however certain individuals whose contribution to the campaign or whose mission was vital were classified "BIGOT", and were flown to Africa on a safer route via Gibraltar.<ref name="spycraft">{{cite book |last1=Melton |first1=H. Keith |first2=Robert |last2=Wallace |first3=Henry Robert |last3=Schlesinger |title=Spycraft |year=2011 |publisher=Random House |isbn = 1-4464-9776-3}}</ref>
Several sources state that BIGOT was a codeword for [[Operation Overlord]], the [[Allies of World War II|Western Allies]]' plan to invade German-occupied western Europe during [[World War II]], and that the term was an acronym for "British Invasion of German Occupied Territory".<ref name="hotw">{{Cite web |last=Fitzgerald |first=Tony |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/ahistoryoftheworld/objects/dc7Vms21Qz6Q4xiqgS37xQ |title=BIGOT security classification stamp |website=A History of the World |publisher=BBC/The British Museum}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Obituary: Ronald Fitzgerald |first=Tony |last=Fitzgerald |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/aug/25/ronald-fitzgerald-obituary |newspaper=The Guardian |date=25 August 2011 |accessdate=4 December 2011}}</ref> However, the term "BIGOT", used to designate the highest level of military secrecy, appeared on amphibious operations planning documents prior to Operation Overlord. See, for example, the BIGOT map created for use in Operation Husky, the invasion of Sicily, which took place in 1943, preceding Operation Overlord, which occurred in 1944. This map is referenced on the British Imperial War Museum site<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.iwm.org.uk/collections/item/publication/120304 |title=Bigot - Husky most secret : [map] |website=[[Imperial War Museum]]}}</ref> It is possible that the term itself, supposedly suggested by [[Winston Churchill]], was a "[[backronym]]"—a phrase created to fit an [[acronym]] such as the existing "To Gibraltar" code.
The list of personnel cleared to know details of Overlord was known as the BIGOT list, and the people on it were known as "Bigots". The details of the invasion plan were so secret, adherence to the list was rigidly enforced. U.S. military advisor [[George Elsey]] tells a story in his memoirs about how a junior officer turned away [[George VI|King George VI]] from the intelligence centre on the {{USS|Ancon|AGC-4|6}}, because, as he explained to a superior officer "...nobody told me he was a Bigot."<ref name=natgeo /><ref name="elsey">{{cite book |last=Elsey |first=George |authorlink=George Elsey |title=An Unplanned Life |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=7jZ3AAAAMAAJ&pg=PA52 |accessdate=9 December 2011 |year=2005 |publisher=University of Missouri Press |isbn=0-8262-1622-6 |page=52}}</ref>
Although both derivations are of British origin, the term is widely used in the United States intelligence agencies.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Watson |first1=Bruce |first2=Susan M. |last2=Watson |first3=Gerald W. |last3=Hopple |title=United States intelligence: an encyclopedia |year=1990 |publisher=Garland |isbn=0-8240-3713-8}}</ref>

{{close paraphrasing|date=February 2017|source=http://sncclegacyproject.org/robert-c-mants-jr}} {{Infobox person | name = Bob Mants | image = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = Robert Mants | birth_date = {{Birth date|1943|04|25}} | birth_place = [[East Point, Georgia]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|2011|12|07|1943|04|25}} | death_place = [[Atlanta, Georgia]] | nationality = | other_names = | occupation = Civil rights activist; politician | years_active = 1964–2011 | known_for = field secretary for [[Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee|SNCC]], leading [[Selma to Montgomery marches]] | notable_works = | alma_mater = | spouse = Joann Christian
(m. 1965?–2011, his death) | children = 3 (2 daughters, 1 son) }} '''Robert C. "Bob" Mants, Jr.''' (April 25, 1943 – December 7, 2011) was an American civil rights activist, serving as a field secretary for the [[Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee]] (SNCC). He helped lead [[Selma to Montgomery marches|the voting rights march from Selma to Montgomery]]; he was standing in the second rank (with [[Albert Turner (civil rights activist)|Albert Turner]], behind [[Hosea Williams]] and [[John Lewis (Georgia politician)|John Lewis]]) on [[Bloody Sunday (1965)|Bloody Sunday]]. After Selma, Mants moved to [[Lowndes County, Alabama|Lowndes County]], working for civil rights for the remainder of his life. Lowndes County contained the majority of the distance covered by the Selma to Montgomery march, and was then notorious for its racist violence. ==Early life== Mants was born in [[East Point, Georgia]]. He graduated in 1961 from East Point/South Fulton High School,{{cite web |url=http://sncclegacyproject.org/robert-c-mants-jr |title=Robert "Bob" Mants (1943–2011) |author=Kranz, Sharlene |date=7 December 2011 |publisher=SNCC Legacy Project |accessdate=21 February 2017}} a segregated black high school. While he was attending high school, Mants was a member of the [[Committee on Appeal for Human Rights]] (which would later develop into the [[Atlanta Student Movement]]) and volunteering for administrative tasks at the headquarters of the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee, two blocks from his home.{{cite web |url=https://snccdigital.org/people/bob-mants/ |title=Bob Mants: April 25, 1943–December 7, 2011; Raised in Atlanta, Georgia |author= |date=2012 |website=SNCC Digital |publisher=Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee |accessdate=21 February 2017}} He would go on to attend [[Morehouse College]] with the intention of majoring in medicine, but left without graduating, working in 1964 with SNCC in [[Americus, Georgia]]. Afterwards, he would move on to Lowndes County in early 1965. ==Civil rights activism== {{quote |text=''Bob Mants'' ''(he's built on what they see in him'' ''and what he sees in them)'' ''teaches that'' ''being country black'' ''is'' ''a'' ''proud'' ''thing'' |author=[[Charles E. Cobb Jr.|Charlie Cobb Jr.]] (1965)}} While in Americus, Mants reported over the [[Wide Area Telephone Service]] that "negro and white" mobs were forming on the evening of July 6, 1964, possibly in response to riots the evening before or the integration of two downtown restaurants earlier in the day, which had occurred without incident. Mants was working to calm and disperse the mobs. An hour later, Mants reported a drive-by shooting with no reported injuries or deaths.{{cite report |url=http://cdm15932.contentdm.oclc.org/cdm/ref/collection/p15932coll2/id/24020 |title=King—July, 1964 WATS Line Calls |author=King, Mary E. |date=1962–1999 |publisher=Wisconsin Historical Society: Freedom Summer Collection |accessdate=21 February 2017}} Mants and [[Stokely Carmichael]] from the SNCC first arrived in Selma to participate in the 1965 Selma-to-Montgomery march; in photographs of Bloody Sunday taken by [[Spider Martin]], Mants can be seen wearing a patterned cap, marching next to Albert Turner just behind John Lewis after crossing the [[Edmund Pettus Bridge]];{{cite web |url=http://www.spidermartin.com/image-gallery/x3g93wop9oi0brr0tjwp54kfsoas96 |title=1/5 'Selma 1965 Bloody Sunday': Hosea Williams and John Lewis leading marchers over the Alabama River |author=Martin, Spider |date=7 March 1965 |publisher=Spider Martin |accessdate=21 February 2017}}{{cite web |url=http://www.spidermartin.com/image-gallery/rxtx0c3nbgkjd4gn6gkdr6uzxvel9h |title=1/7 'Two Minute Warning': Hosea Williams and John Lewis confront troopers on Bloody Sunday |author=Martin, Spider |date=7 March 1965 |publisher=Spider Martin |accessdate=21 February 2017}} earlier that morning, Mants had participated in a prayer at the [[Brown Chapel A.M.E. Church (Selma, Alabama)|Brown Chapel A.M.E. Church]], where the march originated, with John Lewis, Hosea Williams, and [[Andrew Young]].{{cite web |url=http://www.stevenkasher.com/exhibitions/selma-march-1965?view=slider#2 |title=Bob Mants, John Lewis, Hosea Williams and Andrew Young with Brown's Chapel AME Church in the Background |author=Martin, Spider |date=7 March 1965 |publisher=Steven Kasher Gallery |accessdate=21 February 2017}} During the violent suppression on Bloody Sunday, Mants saved a woman from a possible beating and took her away from the tear gas cloud. While marching to Montgomery in late March 1965, Mants was passing out buttons and leaflets when a resident of Lowndes County, pleased the civil rights movement was coming to her, memorably quoted [[Revelation 7]]:9 to him. In 1964, Lowndes County had no registered black voters,{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2002/03/14/us/ex-black-militant-gets-life-for-murdering-deputy.html |title=Ex-Black Militant Gets Life for Murdering Deputy |author=Firestone, David |date=14 March 2002 |newspaper=The New York Times |accessdate=21 February 2017}} even though the county's population was predominantly black.{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/05/us/a-selma-march-relives-those-first-steps-of-65.html |title=A Selma March Relives Those First Steps of '65 |author=Smothers, Ronald |date=5 March 1990 |newspaper=The New York Times |accessdate=21 February 2017 |quote=Two months after Bloody Sunday, Robert Mants said as he marched today, an organization he was in got to work in nearby Lowndes County, which was 81 percent black and had fewer than 30 black registered voters and no black elected officials.}} The county was known as "Bloody Lowndes" or the rusty buckle of the [[Black Belt (region of Alabama)|Black Belt of Alabama]] because of its long, violent history of whites retaliating against blacks who tried to register to vote.{{cite book |url=https://nyupress.org/books/9780814743317/ |title=Bloody Lowndes: Civil Rights and Black Power in Alabama's Black Belt |author=Jeffries, Hasan Kwame |date=August 2010 |isbn=978-0-81474-331-7 |publisher=New York University Press |location=New York, New York |accessdate=21 February 2017}}{{cite interview |subject=Bob Mants |interviewer=Carroll Blue |date=18 October 1988 |publisher=Washington University Libraries, Film and Media Archive, Henry Hampton Collection |accessdate=21 February 2017 |title=Eyes on the Prize II: America at the Racial Crossroads 1965 to 1985 |url=http://digital.wustl.edu/cgi/t/text/text-idx?c=eop;cc=eop;rgn=main;view=text;idno=man5427.0175.102}} When Mants and other SNCC officials began to register black voters, the newly registered voters, many of which still lived on plantations, were made homeless by the predominantly white landowners. Many of the displaced black residents were housed in a temporary "Tent City" and subject to intimidation over the next two years as shots were regularly fired into the encampment. In response, SNCC set up the [[Alabama Poor People's Land Fund]] to purchase plots of land and building materials to help the displaced black residents to build new homes. SNCC also tried a new strategy in Lowndes County, setting up the [[Lowndes County Freedom Organization]] (LCFO) in 1966 as an independent Black political party, adopting a snarling black panther as its logo. LCFO would in turn inspire other leaders, such as Stokely Carmichael, who adopted the structure of LCFO for [[Black Power]], and [[Bobby Seale]] and [[Huey P. Newton]], who adopted the black panther logo for the [[Black Panther Party]]. Mants remained in Lowndes County after the march, saying "if there was any place I wanted to raise my kids, it would be here, because they could see black people moving forward, advancing ourselves as a race."{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1994/08/02/us/in-selma-everything-and-nothing-changed.html?pagewanted=all |title=In Selma, Everything and Nothing Changed |author=Applebome, Peter |date=2 August 1994 |newspaper=The New York Times |accessdate=21 February 2017}} Mants served as a farm management specialist at [[Tuskegee University]]. In 1984, Mants was elected to the Lowndes County Commission, unseating a white incumbent, and served one term. In 2000, Mants opposed the creation of a landfill along [[U.S. Route 80]], the highway taken by marchers in the third Selma to Montgomery march, calling it "an insult." As head of Lowndes County Friends of the Trail, he noted "you can't commemorate [the route of the march] on the one hand and desecrate it on the other."{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2000/10/02/us/at-odds-in-alabama-over-a-landfill-on-a-historic-trail.html |title=At Odds in Alabama Over a Landfill on a Historic Trail |author=Sengupta, Somini |date=2 October 2000 |newspaper=The New York Times |accessdate=21 February 2017}} Bob Mants died after a heart attack on December 7, 2011, while visiting Atlanta.{{cite news |url=http://www.montgomeryadvertiser.com/story/news/local/selma50/2015/03/01/never-one-promote-mants-part-legacy/24214269/ |title=Never one to promote himself, Mants was part of legacy |author=Benn, Alvin |date=1 March 2015 |newspaper=Montgomery Advertiser |accessdate=21 February 2017}} A memorial service was held in Lowndes County on December 17, 2011, where several speakers praised him and his three children (Kadejah, Kumasi, and Katanga) expressed their appreciation for the honors bestowed to him. In addition to his three children, Mants is survived his wife, Joann Christian (also a noted civil rights activist) and seven grandchildren. ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== * [https://snccdigital.org/people/bob-mants/ SNCC Digital Gateway: Bob Mants], Documentary website created by the SNCC Legacy Project and Duke University, telling the story of the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee & grassroots organizing from the inside-out * {{vimeo |id=119453703 |title=We Shall Not Be Moved: The Life and Times of the SNCC 1960–1966, Part H}}. Part of a 10-part series of videorecordings of a conference entitled ''We Shall Not Be Moved: The Life and Times of the SNCC, 1960–1966'' held at [[Trinity College (Connecticut)|Trinity College]], [[Hartford, Connecticut]], on 14–16 April 1988. * {{vimeo |id=33352305 |title=Voices of Freedom: Bob Mants}}. "My maternal grandfather ... was born a slave, had witnessed slavery, and he had also witnessed freedom. The notion of his enslavement and him being able to witness the freedom empowered me for the moment. And it still does." * {{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ngSC1iaW_x8C&pg=PA128#v=onepage&q&f=false |title=Hands on the Freedom Plow: Personal Accounts by Women in SNCC |author=Mants, Joann Christian |date=2010 |publisher=University of Illinois Press |location=Urbana-Champaign, Illinois |isbn=978-0-252-03557-9 |editor1=Holsaert, Faith S. |editor2=Noonan, Martha Prescod Norman |editor3=Richardson, Judy |editor4=Robinson, Betty Garman |editor5=Young, Jean Smith |editor6=Zellner, Dorothy M. |pages=128–140 |chapter=We Turned This Upside-Down Country Right Side Up |accessdate=21 February 2017}} * {{cite web |url=http://www.crmvet.org/mem/mantsb.htm |title=Robert "Bob" Mants (1943–2011) |author=Kranz, Sharlene |date=8 December 2011 |publisher=SNCC Legacy Project |website=Civil Rights Movement Veterans |accessdate=21 February 2017}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Mants, Bob}} [[Category:Civil rights activists]] [[Category:20th-century African-American activists]] [[Category:Anti-racism activists]] [[Category:People from Georgia (U.S. state)]] [[Category:1943 births]] [[Category:2011 deaths]] [[Category:Selma to Montgomery marches]]

The '''Caleb Foundation''', created in 1998,<ref name="NL interview">[http://www.newsletter.co.uk/news/politics/latest/it-is-unfair-to-compare-us-to-the-taliban-1-2379745 ''[[The News Letter]]''], interview with Wallace Thompson, 4 February 2011</ref> is one of the leading [[creationism|creationist]] pressure groups in [[Northern Ireland]]. It also lobbies on a range of social policy issues such as [[abortion]] and [[same-sex marriage]] from an [[evangelicalism|evangelical]] [[Protestant]] perspective, and has been particularly influential with [[Democratic Unionist Party]] ministers in the [[Northern Ireland Executive]].<ref name="Clarke2">[https://wayback.archive-it.org/all/20120902014242/http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/news/politics/creationist-bible-group-and-its-web-of-influence-at-stormont-16205034.html "Creationist Bible group and its web of influence at Stormont"], Liam Clarke, ''[[Belfast Telegraph]]'' 1 September 2012</ref> The Foundation describes its mission as "promoting the fundamentals of the historic evangelical Protestant faith".<ref name="CF">{{cite web|url = http://www.calebfoundation.org/ | publisher = Calebfoundation.org | title = Caleb Foundation website | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20150307200052/http://www.calebfoundation.org/ | archivedate = 7 March 2015 }}</ref>
==Structure, leadership and influence== The Foundation was launched at a meeting held in the Park Avenue Hotel, [[Belfast]] on 16 October 1998,<ref>[http://www.takeheed.net/News_From_The_Front/news8.htm ''News from the Front''], Take Heed Ministries, December 1998</ref> following an initial meeting in Ballymoney in February 1998 attended by delegates from a number of small evangelical Protestant churches. It is not a membership organisation.<ref name="Clarke2"/>
The Foundation is led by a "Council of Reference" including ministers, pastors and other activists from a variety of small Protestant sects. The largest single denomination represented is the [[Free Presbyterian Church (Ulster)|Free Presbyterian Church]] founded by Rev. [[Ian Paisley]],<ref name="CF"/><ref name="NL interview"/> with others including the [[Congregational church#Ireland|Congregational Union of Ireland]], the [[Evangelical Presbyterian Church (Ireland)|Evangelical Presbyterian]], [[Methodism#Ireland|Independent Methodist]], [[Association of Baptist Churches in Ireland|Baptist]], [[Reformed Presbyterian Church of Ireland|Reformed Presbyterian]], [[Congregational Reformed Church|Congregational Reformed]] and [[Elim Pentecostal Church|Elim Pentecostal]] churches, the [[Church of the Nazarene]] and the Evangelical Protestant Society. Prominent members of the Council (in 2012) include [[Ron Johnstone]], who succeeded Paisley as leader of the Free Presbyterian Church; DUP MLA [[Mervyn Storey]], also a Free Presbyterian; Philip Campbell, Convenor of the Public Morals Committee of the Congregational Union, and Free Presbyterian minister Alan Smylie,<ref name="CF"/> who conducted the funeral service for [[Shankill Butchers|Shankill Butcher]] [[Robert Bates (loyalist)|Robert Bates]].<ref>Steve Bruce, ''Paisley: Religion and Politics in Northern Ireland'', Oxford University Press, 2007, p. 221</ref>
Its first chairman, until his death in 2007, was [[George Dawson (Northern Ireland politician)|George Dawson]], an activist in Paisley's Democratic Unionist Party (DUP) and subsequently a DUP [[Member of the Legislative Assembly (Northern Ireland)|MLA]]. Dawson was Grand Master of the [[Independent Orange Order]] and Treasurer of the [[Evangelical Protestant Society]].<ref name="BCSE"/> On his death, Rev. William Park became acting chairman.<ref name="CF"/> Its secretary for some time after the launch in 1998, David McConaghie acted until late 2012 as its press spokesman, and held other offices in the Foundation's Council of Reference. Wallace Thompson of the Evangelical Protestant Society, who had been the Foundation's treasurer since 1998,<ref name="CF"/> succeeded as chairman of the Foundation in September 2009,<ref>[http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/news/politics/exdup-adviser-to-lead-evangelical-group-of-lobbyists-14512725.html?startindex=20 ''[[Belfast Telegraph]]''] news report, 28 September 2009</ref> Park becoming vice-chairman.<ref name="CF"/> Thompson, who was a founding member of the DUP, is also an [[Orange Order|Orangeman]], a former [[Northern Ireland Office]] civil servant, and a former ministerial adviser to [[Nigel Dodds]]. It was while employed in the last role, in 2008, that Thompson in a radio interview denounced the [[Pope]] as the [[Antichrist]].<ref name="NL interview"/> Thompson is a member of the Public Morals Committee of the Evangelical Presbyterian Church.<ref name="BCSE"/> The secretary of the Foundation is Rev. Philip Campbell, Congregational minister in Coleraine. who replaced Rev Robert McEvoy in June 2013. This change formed part of an organisational re-structuring of the Foundation with the establishment of a steering committee which is empowered to make decisions and respond to events.
Documenting the influence of the Foundation within Northern Ireland [[Unionism in Ireland|unionist]] politics, and particularly the DUP, the ''[[Belfast Telegraph]]'' noted in 2012 that politicians close to it included Northern Ireland [[Minister of Health, Social Services and Public Safety|health minister]] [[Edwin Poots]], [[Minister for Social Development]] [[Nelson McCausland]], junior minister [[Jonathan Bell (politician)|Jonathan Bell]], [[Diane Dodds]] [[Member of the European Parliament|MEP]], [[Gregory Campbell (politician)|Gregory Campbell]] [[Member of Parliament#United Kingdom|MP]], [[David Simpson (Northern Ireland politician)|David Simpson]] MP, [[Paul Givan]] MLA, [[Stephen Moutray]] MLA (and mayor of [[Craigavon]]), [[Jim Allister]], leader of [[Traditional Unionist Voice]] and TUV press officer and [[East Antrim (UK Parliament constituency)|East Antrim]] parliamentary candidate Sammy Morrison.<ref name="Clarke2"/> A leading ''Belfast Telegraph'' journalist wrote on another occasion that "Caleb plays a role within the DUP analogous to the old [[Militant tendency]] within the [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour]] party."<ref name="Clarke">[http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/opinion/why-good-book-could-be-bad-news-for-dup-14832896.html] Liam Clarke, "Why Good Book could be bad news for DUP", ''[[Belfast Telegraph]]'', 7 June 2010</ref> Also in 2012, the ''[[Irish Daily Star]]'' noted that Caleb "claims a support base of 200,000 evangelicals" and asked whether it had "overtaken the Orange Order as the most influential pressure group within Unionism".<ref>[http://www.nuzhound.com/articles/Daily_Star/arts2012/sep17_Caleb_Foundation__JCoulter_Star.php "Caleb Foundation is on a mission"], John Coulter, ''[[Irish Daily Star]]'', n.d. 2012</ref>
==Activities== {{Refimprove section|date=November 2015}} The Foundation's lobbying to have public bodies give at least equal coverage to creationist beliefs as to scientific evidence of [[evolution]] came to attention in 1999, when McConaghie wrote in the Belfast ''[[News Letter]]'' in response to the [[BBC]] television series ''[[Walking with Dinosaurs]]'', calling for "equal prominence to be given to the Creation creed".<ref>[http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-61078631.html Archive link] to David McConaghie, "How did it all begin?", ''[[News Letter]]'', 19 October 1999</ref>
In 2006 McConaghie met senior officers of the [[Police Service of Northern Ireland]] to discuss the Foundation's request that figures for 'gay-on-gay' violence in Northern Ireland be collated and published, and that police figures for 'cohabiting same-sex' domestic violence be made available to the Foundation "for analysis".<ref>[http://www.zoominfo.com/CachedPage/?archive_id=0&page_id=2001716842&page_url=//www.calebfoundation.org/page16.htm Cached version of Caleb website]</ref>
In 2008 the Foundation's spokesman called for the banning of the Belfast [[Pride parade|Gay Pride parade]], complaining of the "gratuitously offensive and deliberately provocative behaviour emanating from participants".<ref>"Clergyman urges others to join Gay Pride march", ''[[News Letter]]'', 4 August 2008</ref> Also in 2008, the Foundation's website carried a photograph of a shop window display in [[Enniskillen]] and asked: "Is one of Northern Ireland's leading clothes chains promoting homosexuality?", pointing out "a pair of female mannikins [sic.] in the window of their Enniskillen store, holding hands."<ref>Archived version of http://www.calebfoundation.org/</ref>
The Foundation lobbied the [[Ulster Museum]] in 2010 to feature creationist theories in its displays. The Foundation wrote to DUP minister [[Nelson McCausland]] and to [[Ulster Museum|National Museums Northern Ireland]] to express their concerns about the Museum's Nature Zone exhibits which described evolution as fact.<ref>[http://www.bbc.co.uk/blogs/ni/2010/05/creationism_and_the_ulster_mus.html "Creationism and the Ulster Museum"], [[BBC Northern Ireland]], 28 May 2010</ref> McCausland subsequently wrote to the Museum trustees calling for alternative views of the origin of the universe to be accommodated in the museum's natural history displays.<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/belief/2010/jun/19/creationism-northern-ireland ''[[The Guardian]]''], 19 June 2010</ref>
In 2010 the [[British Centre for Science Education]] published an 11,000-word report which accused the Foundation of promoting [[Christofascism|Christian fascism]] and [[Dominionism]], aiming to make Northern Ireland a "fundamentalist Protestant theocracy".<ref name="BCSE">[http://www.bcseweb.org.uk/index.php/Main/CalebFoundation [[British Centre for Science Education]]] report on Caleb, 2010</ref>
In 2011-12 the Foundation's press officer, David McConaghie, by then a full-time DUP official, lobbied two DUP ministers in the [[Northern Ireland Executive]] - McCausland and [[Arlene Foster]] - to have creationist theories included in displays at the new visitor centre at the [[Giant's Causeway]].<ref name="NL interview"/> The lobbying involved other DUP members and evangelical churches.<ref>[http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/news/local-national/northern-ireland/dup-aide-quizzed-over-toilet-camera-16238776.html [[Belfast Telegraph]]] news report, 16 November 2012</ref><ref name="daily">[http://www.belfastdaily.co.uk/2012/11/16/dup-spy-aide-arrested-and-quizzed-over-covert-toilet-camera-device/ Belfastdaily.co.uk] news report, 16 November 2012</ref> The [[National Trust]] included a "younger Earth" version of the origins of the Giant's Causeway at the visitor centre.<ref name="ITimes"/> In July 2012 McConaghie welcomed this as "recognition of the view, held by scientists right across the spectrum, that the scientific evidence points to a much younger age of the universe and to the direct involvement of a Divine Creator."<ref>[http://www.newsletter.co.uk/news/david-mcconaghie-causeway-creationist-feature-promotes-healthy-debate-1-4038102 ''[[The News Letter]]''], 10 July 2012</ref> However, following widespread objections to the creationist content, the National Trust removed the display in October 2012.<ref>https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-northern-ireland-19814284</ref>
The Foundation has also lobbied for more representation by evangelical churches on [[BBC Northern Ireland]], and in opposition to the relaxation of Sunday trading laws,<ref name="NL interview"/> the extension of gay rights, Sunday sport,<ref name="Clarke"/> a [[Marie Stopes International|Marie Stopes]] clinic in Belfast and [[same-sex marriage]].<ref name="ITimes"/> McConaghie met senior personnel from education bodies to lobby for the inclusion of a creationist viewpoint in the Northern Ireland curriculum.<ref name="ITimes">[http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/breaking/2012/1116/breaking34.html [[The Irish Times]]] news report, 16 November 2012</ref> Other issues on which the Caleb Foundation has lobbied include the reform of prostitution laws, raising the retail price of alcohol and limiting pub opening hours, opposing the review of the [[abortion law]]s to include rape and foetal abnormality, and banning of [[LGBT adoption|gay adoption]]. While it did not specifically lobby for a ban on [[blood donation]] by gay men, it "approved of the position of the minister" Edwin Poots in retaining the ban.<ref name="Clarke2"/>
In November 2012 the Caleb Foundation announced that McConaghie had "voluntarily stepped down" from his role as its press officer, after he was arrested and charged with concealing a camera in a toilet cubicle for purposes of sexual gratification.<ref name="CF"/><ref>[https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/northern-ireland-mp-former-aide-davidmcconaghie-arrested-over-toilet-camera-8323672.html [[The Independent]]], 16 November 2012</ref><ref>[http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/news/local-national/northern-ireland/exdup-aide-david-mcconaghie-appears-in-court-charged-with-voyeurism-30611606.html [[Belfast Telegraph]]], 24 September 2014</ref><ref>[http://www.irishnews.com/news/2015/12/17/news/ex-dup-adviser-david-mcconaghie-s-appeal-dismissed-356322/ [[The Irish News]]], 16 December 2015</ref> In October 2015, McConaghie who used a secret camera to spy on women in toilet, was convicted of voyeurism.<ref>https://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/news/northern-ireland/no-reaction-no-explanation-and-no-apology-as-dup-aide-david-mcconaghie-who-used-a-secret-camera-to-spy-on-women-in-toilet-is-convicted-of-voyeurism-31480991.html</ref>
