{{Infobox book | name = Report about Case Srebrenica (the first part) | title_orig = | translator = | image = Case srebrenica cover.jpg | caption = Report cover (2002) | author = Darko Trifunović | illustrator = | cover_artist = | country = Bosnia and Herzegovina | language = English | series = | subject = [[Srebrenica massacre]] | genre = | publisher = Republika Srpska Government Bureau for Relations with the International Criminal Tribunal for the Former Yugoslavia | pub_date = September 2002 | english_pub_date = | pages = 139 | isbn = | oclc = 180899246 | preceded_by = | followed_by = }} '''''Report about Case Srebrenica (the first part)''''' was a controversial official report on the July 1995 [[Srebrenica massacre]] in eastern [[Bosnia and Herzegovina]]. It was prepared by Darko Trifunović<ref name="Rozajać">{{cite news|last=Rozajać|first=Sanita|title=Europe Finds Interesting Trifunovic's Story about Islamic Terrorism|work=Oslobodjenje|publisher=via BBC Monitoring|date=16 January 2008}}</ref><ref name="Hayat">{{cite news|title=Bosnian Muslims object to Serb terrorism expert addressing European conference|work=TV Hayat|publisher=via BBC Monitoring|date=7 January 2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Brief Record|url=http://catalog.loc.gov/cgi-bin/Pwebrecon.cgi?DB=local&BBID=15401773&v3=1|publisher=Library of Congress}}</ref> and published by the [[Republika Srpska]] Government Bureau for Relations with the [[International Criminal Tribunal for the Former Yugoslavia]] (ICTY).
The report denied that there had been a massacre at [[Srebrenica]] and accused the [[International Committee of the Red Cross]] of having "fabricated" its findings on the killings. Its claims were strongly criticised by the international community and the [[Bosniak]]s and were eventually disowned by the Republika Srpska government.<ref name="Denial">{{cite news|author1=Tracy, Jen|author2=Rawles, Lee|author3=Krauthamer, Ky|author4=Gardner, Andrew|title=The Death of Denial|url=http://www.tol.org/client/article/10948-the-death-of-denial.html|work=Transitions Online|date=10 November 2003|accessdate=3 July 2009}}</ref> In a judgment against [[Miroslav Deronjić]], the Hague Tribunal judges described the report as "one of the worst examples of revisionism."<ref name="ICTY=Deronjic"/> No "second part" has ever been published.
==Background== In July 1995, forces of the [[Army of the Republika Srpska]] (VRS) captured the town of [[Srebrenica]] in eastern [[Bosnia]], which had been cut off and surrounded despite the presence of soldiers from the [[United Nations Protection Force]] (UNPROFOR). Thousands of refugees had crowded into the town to escape the Serb advance. Following the Serb takeover of Srebrenica, an estimated 8,000 Bosniak men and boys were systematically massacred by Serb forces between 11–15 July and another 25,000–30,000 were subjected to [[ethnic cleansing]]. It was the largest act of [[mass murder]] in Europe since [[World War II]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Briefly Noted|url=http://iwpr.net/report-news/briefly-noted-67|publisher=Institute of War and Peace Reporting|date=18 March 2005}}</ref>
Successive governments of [[Republika Srpska]] (and, for a while, [[Republic of Serbia|Serbia]]) sought to deny the massacre and other [[war crimes]] committed by the VRS during the war.<ref name="Denial" /> It was against this background that, as the former [[United Nations]] trial attorney Mark B. Harmon commented, "the campaign of misinformation and deceit reached its apotheosis seven years after the crimes were committed with the publication of the ''Report About Case Srebrenica (the first part)''."<ref name="Harmon">{{cite journal|author1=Harmon, Mark B.|author2=Gaynor, Fergal|title=Ordinary Sentences for Extraordinary Crimes|url=http://jicj.oxfordjournals.org/content/5/3/683.full?ck=nck|issue=5|year=2007|pages=683–712|journal=Journal of International Criminal Justice}}</ref>
==Contents of the report== [[File:Darko Trifunović.jpg|left|thumb|Darko Trifunović, the author of ''Report about Case Srebrenica'', whose work on the report was strongly criticised.]] The report was promoted as an effort "to present the whole truth about crimes committed in Srebrenica region regardless nationality of perpetrators of crimes and time when they were committed {{sic}}."<ref name="Harmon" /> It asserted that no more than 2,000 [[Bosniaks]] (Bosnian Muslims) had died at Srebrenica – all armed soldiers, not civilians – and that 1,600 of them had died in combat or while trying to escape the enclave.<ref name="Imaginary">{{cite news|author1=Alić, Anes|author2=Stanimirović, Dragan|title=Imaginary Massacres?|url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,349957,00.html|newspaper=Time|date=11 September 2002|subscription=yes}}</ref> It consistently referred to the "alleged massacre", attributed the deaths of about 100 Bosniaks to "exhaustion" and concluded: "the number of Muslim soldiers who were executed by Bosnian Serb forces for personal revenge or for simple ignorance of international law […] would probably stand less than 100."<ref name="ICTY=Deronjic">{{cite web|title=Prosecutor v. Miroslav Deronjić – Sentencing Judgement|url=http://www.icty.org/x/cases/deronjic/tjug/en/sj-040330e.pdf|publisher=International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia|date=30 March 2004|page=69}}</ref> The report dismissed as "mentally disturbed" a Bosnian Serb soldier who had admitted participating in the killings, and claimed that the survivors' stories were a product of their imaginations: "To walk for almost 20 days in an area that might be full of landmines, without any food and water, under the fear of being shot from any direction was such a trauma that soldiers sometimes mixed reality with illusions. Having looked at dead bodies under such psychological [pressure], some Muslim soldiers could have believed what they imagined."<ref name="Imaginary"/> It asserted that "this combat might have looked like a mass killing in the eyes of frightened Muslim soldiers, although they carried weapons and shot at Bosnian Serb soldiers randomly."<ref name="Subotic">{{cite news|last=Subotic|first=Tanja|title=Bosnian Serbs seek to minimize Srebrenica killings|publisher=Agence France-Presse|date=3 September 2002}}</ref>
The report also asserted that the findings of the [[International Committee of the Red Cross]] and other humanitarian organisations had been "manipulated" and "fabricated".<ref name="Denial" /> It characterised Serbs as the victims of Bosniak war crimes around Srebrenica,<ref name="Fischer">{{cite book|author1=Fischer|author2=McDonald, Avril|title=Yearbook of International Humanitarian Law – 2002|pages=453–454|publisher=Asser Press|year=2005|ISBN=90-6704-189-0}}</ref> asserting that in 1992 and 1993 alone 1300 Serb civilians were killed.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Dragnich |first=Alex |date=Autumn–Winter 2002 |title=Srebrenica: No Definitive Verdict Yet|journal=The South Slav Journal |issue=89/90 |pages=23–29}}</ref> This figure has been shown to be inaccurate, and the true number "three to nine times smaller", by the [[Research and Documentation Center in Sarajevo]], a non-partisan institution with a multi-ethnic staff, whose data have been collected, processed, checked, compared and evaluated by an international team of experts.<ref>{{cite news|title=Mit o Bratuncu: Sramotna Manipulacija Brojevima |trans-title=Myth of Bratunac: Shameful Manipulation of Numbers |publisher=Research and Documentation Center in Sarajevo |url=http://www.idc.org.ba/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=259:bratunac&catid=115:ljudski-gubici-ostalo&Itemid=147&lang=bs |date=7 June 2010 |language=Serbo-Croatian |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110623234049/http://www.idc.org.ba/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=259:bratunac&catid=115:ljudski-gubici-ostalo&Itemid=147&lang=bs |archivedate=June 23, 2011 }}</ref> The instigator of the massacre, General [[Ratko Mladić]], was mentioned only in the context of demanding the surrender of the town and evacuating civilians; the report asserted that he had tried "discouraging Serbs to take their wild revenge."<ref name="Subotic" /> The report claimed that "the Muslims inflated the number [of deaths] in order to accomplish what they wanted from the very beginning – to involve the international community in the conflict with Serbs."<ref name="Newsline040902">{{cite news|title=Newsline – September 4, 2002|publisher=Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty|url=http://www.rferl.org/content/article/1142751.html|date=4 September 2002}}</ref>
According to Dejan Miletić, whom [[Paddy Ashdown]], the High Representative for Bosnia and Herzegovina, removed in April 2004 from his post as Head of the Republika Srpska Secretariat for Relations with the [[International Criminal Tribunal for the Former Yugoslavia|International Criminal Tribunal in The Hague]] and Research of War Crimes, the report "had based its conclusions on publications found on the Internet, reports from the United Nations and other sources." It was intended to be sent to lawyers defending Bosnian Serbs on trial for war crimes.<ref name="Subotic" />
==ICTY verdict== The ICTY reviewed the "Report About Case Srebrenica" and concluded the following:
{{quote|The Trial Chamber admitted into evidence a document which represents one of the worst examples of revisionism in relation to the mass executions of Bosnian Muslims committed in Srebrenica in July 1995. This document, titled “Report about Case Srebrenica (the First Part)” was prepared by the Documentation Centre of Republika Srpska, Bureau of Government of Republika Srpska for Relation with ICTY on 1 September 2002. Throughout this report reference is made to the “alleged massacre” and this misrepresentation of the historical events culminates in the final conclusion of this report, which reads: […] the number of Muslim soldiers who were executed by Bosnian Serb forces for personal revenge or for simple ignorance of international law […] would probably stand less than 100.<ref name="ICTY=Deronjic"/> }}
==Reactions== [[File:Srebrenica massacre memorial gravestones 2009 1.jpg|300px|thumb|The cemetery at the [[Srebrenica Genocide memorial|Srebrenica-Potočari Memorial and Cemetery to Genocide Victims]]]] After the report was published on 3 September 2002, it was condemned by a wide variety of Bosnian and international figures.<ref name="IWPR-Bosnian Serbs">{{cite news|last=Katana|first=Gordana|title=Bosnian Serbs Play Down Srebrenica|url=http://iwpr.net/report-news/regional-report-bosnian-serbs-play-down-srebrenica|publisher=Institute of War and Peace Reporting|date=30 April 2005|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130221155015/http://iwpr.net/report-news/regional-report-bosnian-serbs-play-down-srebrenica|archivedate=21 February 2013|df=}}</ref> A spokesman for the ICTY told [[Radio Free Europe]] that "any claim that the number of victims after the fall of the Srebrenica enclave was around the 2,000 mark, and most of those killed in battle, is an absolutely outrageous claim. It's utterly false, and it flies in the face of all of the evidence painstakingly collected in the investigation into the tragedy."<ref>{{cite news|title=Bosnia: New Bosnian Serb Report Denies Srebrenica Massacre|publisher=Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty|url=http://www.rferl.org/content/article/1100678.html|date=3 September 2002}}</ref> He described the effort to minimise the number of victims as "frankly, disgusting."<ref name="Newsline030902">{{cite news|title=Newsline – September 3, 2002|publisher=Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty|url=http://www.rferl.org/content/article/1142750.html|date=3 September 2002}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Balkan Report: September 6, 2002|publisher=Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty|url=http://www.rferl.org/content/article/1341079.html|date=6 September 2002}}</ref> [[Carla del Ponte]], the chief prosecutor of the ICTY, described the report's authors as "totally blind, profoundly insensitive and clearly willing to obstruct all efforts to find reconciliation, truth and justice."<ref name="SETimes-Srebrenica" /> Del Ponte's legal adviser, Jean-Jacques Joris, criticised the report as "a saddening example of revisionism and an element which certainly stands in the way of reconciliation in the region."<ref name="Newsline030902" /> The ICTY prosecutors subsequently used the report as evidence in the trial in 2004 of [[Miroslav Deronjić]]; in their verdict, the judges called it "one of the worst examples of revisionism in relation to [the massacre]".<ref name="ICTY=Deronjic" />
[[Paddy Ashdown]], the [[High Representative for Bosnia and Herzegovina]], condemned it as "tendentious, preposterous and inflammatory"<ref name="IWPR-Bosnian Serbs" /><ref>{{cite news|title=International Officials Denounce Bosnian Serb Srebrenica Report – 2002-09-04|url=http://www.voanews.com/content/a-13-a-2002-09-04-24-international-67580632/288499.html|newspaper=Voice of America|date=4 September 2002}}</ref> and "so far from the truth as to be almost not worth dignifying with a response."<ref name="SETimes-Srebrenica">{{cite news|title=New Srebrenica Report Condemned|url=http://www.setimes.com/cocoon/setimes/xhtml/mk/features/setimes/features/2002/09/020904-SVETLA-001|publisher=SETimes.com|date=4 September 2002}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=High Representative condemns Srebrenica report|url=http://www.ohr.int/print/?content_id=27845|archive-url=https://archive.is/20120805084821/http://www.ohr.int/print/?content_id=27845|dead-url=yes|archive-date=5 August 2012|newspaper=Office of the High Representative|date=3 September 2002}}</ref> His office issued a statement calling the report "an irresponsible attempt to deceive voters and to abuse the trauma of massacre survivors".<ref>{{cite news|title=High Representative's office condemns Serb report on Srebrenica|url=http://www.accessmylibrary.com/coms2/summary_0286-9985215_ITM|publisher=SRNA (via BBC Monitoring)|date=3 September 2002}}</ref> Ashdown's spokesman, Julian Braithwaite, noted the report's publication just before elections in the Republika Srpska: "The question for the RS government is why are they publishing this report now, at the time when it could be easily interpreted as irresponsible electioneering. If they are playing down the fact that civilians were massacred and that children are being exhumed from mass graves with their hands tied behind their backs, then that it is outrageous."<ref name="Subotic" /> The [[European Union]] issued a statement calling on "all responsible people and institutions" to reject the study.<ref>{{cite news|title=(Un)Civil Societies Report: September 11, 2002|url=http://fb.rferl.org/content/article/1347280.html|newspaper=Radio Free Europe/Radio Libert|date=11 September 2002}}</ref> The [[International Commission on Missing Persons]] issued a strongly worded statement calling the report a gross distortion of the facts:
{{quote|Manipulation of the issue of the missing for political purposes, including the manipulation of numbers of missing, has been an ongoing practice within Bosnia and Herzegovina that only serves to cause further pain and suffering in a society that has already suffered so much. The study regarding the numbers of missing from the 1995 fall of Srebrenica made by the Republika Srpska's Government Bureau for Relations with the International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia (ICTY) contains what ICMP believes to be serious inaccuracies.<ref name="Imaginary" />}}
The British [[Foreign Office]] minister [[Denis MacShane]] condemned the report as "an insult to the memory of those who died. The authors of this report belong in the same category as those who [[Holocaust denial|deny the Holocaust took place]]."<ref>{{cite web|title=MacShane condemns report denying Srebrenica massacre|url=http://www.wired-gov.net/wg/wg-news-1.nsf/0/1B1424FA443840E1802572AB004B6458?OpenDocument|publisher=Foreign and Commonwealth Office|date=4 September 2002}}</ref> The [[United States]] embassy in Bosnia and Herzegovina urged the Republika Srpska government to withdraw the report, calling it "an attempt to manipulate and divide the public in this country."<ref>{{cite web|title=OHR BiH Media Round-up, 6/9/2002|url=http://www.ohr.int/ohr-dept/presso/bh-media-rep/round-ups/print/?content_id=27870|publisher=Office of the High Representative|date=6 September 2002}}</ref>
Bosnian media, political parties and Srebrenica survivors were likewise strongly critical. The [[Sarajevo]]-based newspaper ''[[Dnevni Avaz]]'' described the report as an attempt by the Bosnian Serb government to deny that [[genocide]] had taken place. The Srebrenica and Zepa Mothers Association condemned the report as "false, shameful and utterly amoral."<ref>{{cite web|title=OHR BiH Media Round-up, 5/9/2002|publisher=Office of the High Representative|url=http://www.ohr.int/ohr-dept/presso/bh-media-rep/round-ups/print/?content_id=27864|date=5 September 2002}}</ref> The [[Party for Bosnia and Herzegovina]] denounced it as "yet another attempt by the Serb Republic authorities in an unscrupulous and brutal way to negate what probably is the worst crime in Europe after WW2."<ref>{{cite news|title=Bosnian party says Serb report on Srebrenica "unscrupulous and brutal"|url=http://www.accessmylibrary.com/coms2/summary_0286-10021477_ITM|publisher=SRNA (via BBC Monitoring)|date=3 September 2002}}</ref><ref name="OHR BiH 4/9/2002">{{cite web|title=OHR BiH Media Round-up, 4/9/2002|url=http://www.ohr.int/ohr-dept/presso/bh-media-rep/round-ups/print/?content_id=27853|publisher=Office of the High Representative|date=4 September 2002}}</ref> [[Alija Behmen]], the Prime Minister of the [[Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina]], called it "a surprising forgery which is trying to delude the public and especially the Serbs in BiH. I honestly believe that this is the last attempt to enliven the policy which marked the tragic past of BiH. Negating the genocide cannot be a part of the election campaign."<ref>{{cite news|title=Bosnian Serb Srebrenica report draws "howls of outrage" from massacre survivors|url=http://www.accessmylibrary.com/coms2/summary_0286-26007382_ITM|publisher=Onasa news agency (via BBC Monitoring)|date=5 September 2002}}</ref>
On the Bosnian Serb side, opinions of the report were initially favourable. The Bosnian Serb media largely supported the report,<ref name="Imaginary" /> and Republika Srpska president [[Mirko Šarović]] (who in October 2002 became the Serb member of the collective [[Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina|presidency]]) said that the report "should not be dismissed out of hand but merits careful study".<ref name="Newsline050902">{{cite news|title=Newsline – September 5, 2002|publisher=Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty|url=http://fb.rferl.org/content/article/1142752.html|date=5 September 2002}}</ref> A number of Bosnian Serb political figures made public statements denying that war crimes had happened<ref name="Imaginary" /> and a government spokesman called the report a bid to promote "truth and reconciliation".<ref name="Newsline040902" /> The Republika Srpska Socialist Party leader, Lazar Ristić, welcomed the report and accused the Bosniak side of having "hitherto presented only false reports, in which names were listed of persons who are still alive today."<ref>{{cite news|title=Bosnian Serb Socialist Party official hails government report on Srebrenica|publisher=SRNA (via BBC Monitoring)|url=http://www.accessmylibrary.com/coms2/summary_0286-25984696_ITM|date=6 September 2002}}</ref>
[[Nikola Špirić]], the speaker of the [[National Assembly of Republika Srpska]], called it "the worst election campaigning I have ever seen."<ref>{{cite news|last=Sito-Sutic|first=Daria|title=Bosnian Serbs face dilemma over Srebrenica denial|date=5 September 2002|publisher=Reuters}}</ref> [[Milorad Dodik]], who was later to become prime minister of Republika Srpska, castigated the report as having been "written by an amateur for the purpose of manipulating public opinion" in advance of the elections and said:
{{quote|It is a political gaffe of the government, since one can see that the report was written several years ago by one man. The report had been written in 1996 and 1997, which goes to show that it does not mention the report by the Netherlands Institute for War Documentation. [...] The government shouldn't have allowed itself to draft such a superficial, amateurish report which put Republika Srpska into such a difficult situation. Responsibility for the consequences of the report's publication must be borne by those who produced it in such a superficial and amateurish way.<ref>{{cite news|title=Bosnian Serb party leader says Srebrenica report is political gaffe|url=http://www.accessmylibrary.com/coms2/summary_0286-9985586_ITM|publisher=FoNet news agency, Belgrade (via BBC Monitoring)|date=6 September 2002}}</ref>}}
The Republika Srpska government was, however, more equivocal. Its prime minister, [[Mladen Ivanić]], accused the media in the [[Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina|Federation entity]] of having "made [a] fuss over the report for their own purposes."<ref name="Imaginary" /> Nonetheless, the outcry from the international community forced the government of Republika Srpska to distance itself from the report, saying that it had not been fully analysed and endorsed:<ref name="IWPR-Bosnian Serbs" />
{{quote|The two studies, which the RS Government's Bureau for Cooperation with the ICTY compiled, are not made by the RS Government. They are part of the report that the RS Government’s Bureau for Cooperation with the ICTY submits to the RS Government every three months. The fact that the Srebrenica report had been condemned by the [[Office of the High Representative]] before the Bureau's news conference was held comes as a surprise. The Bureau representatives clearly said at the news conference that the both reports are to be submitted to the RS Government, which tells us that the OHR based its condemnation on news reports from the BiH Federation media, which said that the Bureau reports are RS Government's report. It also comes as a surprise the fact that the OHR representatives commented on a document, which they have not read. This is another confirmation that the OHR gives in to the pressures coming from the Sarajevo media and that the OHR creates its views by using their [the Sarajevo media's] information and press releases, thus bringing its own [the OHR's] impartiality in question.<ref name="OHR BiH 4/9/2002"/>}}
The Republika Srpska government subsequently disowned the report with Prime Minister Ivanić saying that it was an "unfinished version"<ref name="Denial" /> and "not an attitude of the government of Republika Srpska."<ref>{{cite news|title=Bosnian Serb PM distances himself from controversial massacre report|publisher=Agence France-Presse|date=9 September 2002}}</ref> Two years later, after further pressure from the international community, the Bosnian Serb government issued an official apology for the massacre and admitted that "enormous crimes" had been "committed in the area of Srebrenica in July 1995."<ref>{{cite news|title=Bosnian Serbs issue apology for massacre|url=http://www.bosnia.org.uk/bosrep/report_format.cfm?articleid=1147&reportid=166|publisher=Associated Press|date=11 November 2004}}</ref>
==Notes== {{Reflist|2}}
==External links== * [http://www.slobodan-milosevic.org/documents/srebrenica.pdf Report about Case Srebrenica (The First Part)], slobodan-milosevic.org.

The '''Small Arms Working Group'''('''SAWG''') is an alliance of US-based [[Non-governmental organization|non-governmental groups]] working together to promote change in US and international policies on [[small arms]]. SAWG members believe that [[small arms proliferation]] must be countered by more responsible policies on legal sales and international co-operation to reduce illicit [[Arms trafficking|trafficking]]. Participation in SAWG is open to any organizations that support its objectives.
==See also== * [[Small Arms and Light Weapons]]
==External links== * [http://fas.org/asmp/campaigns/smallarms/sawg.htm Official webpage]
[[Category:Advocacy groups in the United States]] [[Category:Arms control]]

'''Socialist Lebanon''' ({{lang-ar|لبنان الاشتراكي}}) was a small [[Arab nationalism|Arab nationalist]] group in [[Lebanon]]. The group was formed in 1965 by people like Ahmed Beydoun, Waddah Sharara and Fawwaz Trabulsi.
In 1970 the group merged with the [[Organization of Lebanese Socialists]], and formed the [[Communist Action Organization in Lebanon]].
==Sources== *[http://www.bintjbeil.com/A/whois/ahmad_baydoun.html bintjbeil.com]

{{Squatting in the United States}}
'''Take Back the Land''' is an American organisation based in [[Miami]], Florida devoted to blocking [[eviction]]s,<ref name="Jones01042011">{{cite news|url=http://www.michaelmoore.com/words/mike-friends-blog/video-this-is-not-america |title=VIDEO: 'This Is Not America': SWAT Team Evicts Grandmother, Community Fights Back |date=April 1, 2011 |accessdate=April 2, 2011 |work=michaelmoore.com |first=Van |last=Jones}}</ref> and rehousing [[homeless people]] in [[foreclosure|foreclosed houses]].<ref name=usatoday>{{cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/news/nation/2008-12-10-homesquatters_N.htm |title=Homeless turn foreclosures into shelters |date=December 10, 2008 |accessdate=January 4, 2008 |work=[[USA Today]] |first=Rick |last=Jervis}}</ref><ref name=sfgate>{{Cite news|url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2008/12/20/REU514F8BD.DTL |first=Tamara |last=Lush |agency=[[Associated Press]] |date=December 21, 2008 |accessdate=January 4, 2008 |title=Homeless advocates 'liberate' foreclosed houses |work=[[SFGate]] |publisher=[[San Francisco Chronicle]]}}</ref> Take Back the Land was formed in October 2006 to build the [[Umoja Village]] Shantytown on a plot of unoccupied land<ref name="cityPaper">{{cite news |url=http://www.citypaper.com/arts/story.asp?id=17758 |publisher=Baltimore City Paper |date=March 25, 2009 |author=Martin L. Johnson |title=The City From Below |accessdate=April 2, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090416091635/http://www.citypaper.com/arts/story.asp?id=17758 |archivedate=April 16, 2009 |df= }}</ref> to protest [[gentrification]] and a lack of [[low-income housing]] in Miami. The group began opening houses in October 2007<ref name="DemocracyNow!">{{cite news|author=Amy Goodman and Juan Gonzalez| title=Take Back the Land: Miami Grassroots Group Moves Struggling Families into Vacant Homes|publisher =Democracy Now!|url=http://www.democracynow.org/2008/12/19/take_back_the_land_miami_grassroots |date = December 19, 2008 |accessdate=April 2, 2009}}</ref> and moved six homeless families into vacant homes in 2008.<ref name=usatoday/> By April 2009, the group had moved 20 families into foreclosed houses.<ref name="GoodMorn">{{cite news|publisher =Good Morning America|title=Home sweet home? Squatters nab foreclosures|date=April 11, 2009}}</ref> {{Asof|2008|November}}, the group had ten volunteers.<ref name="MiamiNews">{{cite news|url=http://www.miaminewtimes.com/2008-11-20/news/squatters/|publisher=Miami New Times|title=Squatters | author = Natalie O'Neill|date= November 19, 2008 |accessdate=April 2, 2009}}</ref> Take Back the Land volunteers break into the houses, clean, paint and make repairs, change the locks, and help move the homeless families in. They provide supplies and furniture and help residents turn on electricity and water. Though the occupations are of contested legality, {{Asof|2008|December |lc=on}} local police officers were not intervening, judging it to be the responsibility of house owners to protect their property or request assistance.<ref name=sfgate/>
== Advocacy ==
The group advocates for changes in governmental housing policy.<ref name="cityPaper"/> Max Rameau, the homeless advocate running the program, called it "morally indefensible to have vacant homes sitting there, potentially for years, while you have human beings on the street".<ref name=usatoday/> Rameau says that the group only moves families into government- or bank-owned properties, and argues that it is not fair for the banks to be receiving government [[bailout]]s while keeping these assets.<ref name="cnn">{{cite news|publisher=CNN news|date=December 6, 2008|title= Interview with Max Rameau}}</ref>
== Tactics ==
Rameau states that having people occupy the buildings helps the owners by preventing looting and property destruction that he says would likely happen to unoccupied buildings.<ref name="cnn"/><ref name="apmsn"/> He also says that the group requires that tenants get electricity and provides solar panels if the electricity does not work.<ref name="cnn"/> Take Back the Land activists help maintain and clean the yards of the [[squatting|squatted]] houses, and they give the families cleaning supplies and furniture.<ref name="apmsn">{{cite news|date=December 1, 2008|title=Activist moves homeless into foreclosures: Man executes bailout plan of his own on Miami's empty streets |url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/28002276/|accessdate=April 2, 2009|publisher= msnbc.msn.com|author=Associated Press}}</ref> The group gains access to unoccupied houses, paints and cleans them, changes the locks, and connects electricity and water.<ref name="MotherJones">{{cite web|author=Tristram Korten|title=Foreclosure Nation: Squatters or Pioneers?|date=May–June 2008 |publisher=Mother Jones|accessdate=April 2, 2009|url = https://www.motherjones.com/politics/2008/05/foreclosure-nation-squatters-or-pioneers}}</ref> Rameau says each occupation costs the group $200.<ref>{{cite news|title = With Advocates’ Help, Squatters Call Foreclosures Home | publisher=New York Times|author = [[John Leland (journalist)|John Leland]]| accessdate = April 2, 2009|url = https://www.nytimes.com/2009/04/10/us/10squatter.html?_r=2&hp }}</ref> Take Back the Land instructs tenants of the houses to occupy the houses openly; they enter and leave through the front door, pay for utilities in their own names, and are honest with neighbors.<ref name="MiamiNews"/> The families live in the houses they occupy until they either save up enough money to afford to pay for housing or are forcibly evicted by police.<ref name=usatoday/>
The group maintains a waiting list of families who would like to move into foreclosed homes.<ref name="MotherJones"/> Rameau says tenants are carefully chosen in order to avoid creating crack houses; drug addicts are rejected, and participants are assessed for their "urgency of need".<ref name="MiamiNews"/>
According to Rameau, he had approached banks in 2008 with the idea of buying them for a discount price and renting them to homeless people; they seemed interested at first but he says they stopped calling him back after the [[Troubled Assets Relief Program|2008 federal bailout]] was announced.<ref name=usatoday/>
<!--Illegality -->Take Back the Land uses illegal tactics.<ref>{{cite news |title= Homeless find shelter in foreclosed homes |url= http://www.justnews.com/video/18149053/index.html |publisher= justnews.com |author= Channel 10 News |accessdate= April 2, 2009 |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090324015112/http://www.justnews.com/video/18149053/index.html |archivedate= March 24, 2009 |df= }}</ref> The group commits trespassing<ref name="ch10">{{cite news|title=Family Refuses To Leave Foreclosed Home|date= February 23, 2009| url=http://www.justnews.com/news/18779255/detail.html#video |publisher=justnews.com |accessdate=April 2, 2009}}</ref> and tenants could be charged with crimes such as vandalism.<ref name="apmsn"/> Rameau says, "there's a disconnect between the need and the law. Being arrested is just one of the potential factors in doing this."<ref name="apmsn"/> The tenants are told that they may be arrested if caught.<ref name="MotherJones"/> Take Back the Land has a pro-bono lawyer on standby.<ref name="MotherJones"/><ref name="Marketplace">{{cite news|title=Miami's homeless inhabit vacant homes|url=http://marketplace.publicradio.org/display/web/2009/01/28/pm_foreclosure_squatters/|date=January 28, 2009|publisher=NPR Marketplace. American Public Media|author=Kai Ryssdal|accessdate=April 2, 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101205164250/http://marketplace.publicradio.org/display/web/2009/01/28/pm_foreclosure_squatters/|archivedate=December 5, 2010|df=}}</ref> Kelly Penton, a spokeswoman for the city of Miami, said that the city was not taking action to stop Take Back the Land's activities stating that "it is up to the property owner".<ref name="apmsn"/> {{Asof|December 2008}}, police had not gotten involved.<ref name=sfgate/>
== Background == {{see also|Umoja Village}}
Take Back the Land was originally formed in 2006 as an anti-[[gentrification]] organization<ref name="cityPaper"/> inspired by the [[Landless Workers' Movement]] in [[Brazil]] and the [[Western Cape Anti-Eviction Campaign]] in [[South Africa]].<ref>[http://takebacktheland.org/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=99:take-back-the-land-in-south-africa&catid=1:latest-news&Itemid=60 Take Back the Land in South Africa]</ref> The group built the [[Umoja Village]] in Miami in 2006, a shantytown on an undeveloped lot in support of the "black community's right to own land".<ref name="MiamiNews"/> Fifty homeless people lived in the village.<ref name="cityPaper"/> After the village burned down in April 2007, the group moved 14 of the ex-residents into a warehouse.<ref name="MiamiNews"/> Max Rameau released a book detailing the experience entitled ''Take Back the Land: Land, Gentrification and the Umoja Village Shantytown''.<ref>''Take Back the Land: Land, Gentrification and the Umoja Village Shantytown''. {{ISBN|1-4348-4556-7}}</ref>
Partly due to [[overbuilding]] and [[speculation]], Florida, and particularly Miami, have been affected by the housing crisis in the [[late 2000s recession]].<ref name=sfgate/> In September 2008, Florida had the second highest rate of foreclosures in the country.<ref name=sfgate/>
Take Back the Land moved the first family into an unoccupied house on October 22, 2007.<ref name="MiamiNews"/> By November 2008, it had opened up six houses,<ref name="MiamiNews"/> and by April 2009, the group had moved 20 families into foreclosed homes.<ref name="GoodMorn"/>

The '''Professor Thorolf Rafto Memorial Prize''' (''Raftoprisen'') is a [[human rights]] award established in the memory of the [[Norway|Norwegian]] human rights activist, [[Thorolf Rafto]].{{cite web|url=http://www.snl.no/Raftostiftelsen|title=Raftoprisen|author=Vibeke Blaker Strand|publisher=Store norske leksikon|accessdate=21 September 2015}} [https://snl.no/Thorolf_Rafto ''Thorolf Rafto''] Store norske leksikon ==Organization== The prize is awarded annually by the [[Rafto Foundation for Human Rights]] (''Raftostiftelsen'') which was founded in the humanistic tradition of the [[Helsinki Accords]] in order to promote the fundamental human rights of intellectual and political freedom. Today, the foundation is based at the Human Rights House in [[Bergen]], [[Norway]]. The major work of the foundation, including the organization of the award ceremony is done by a small team of professional staff and volunteers. The award ceremony takes place at [[Den Nationale Scene]] in Bergen annually in November.{{cite web|url= https://snl.no/Raftostiftelsen|title= Raftostiftelsen|publisher= Store norske leksikon|author= Jon Gunnar Arntzen |accessdate= November 1, 2017}} The initial idea of the Rafto Prize was to provide a basic informative platform for the laureates that would help to receive further attention from the international media and support from political and non-political organisations. By awarding the Rafto Prize, the Rafto Foundation for Human Rights seeks to bring attention to independent voices that due to oppressive and corruptive regimes are not always heard. For example, four Rafto Laureates have subsequently received further international assistance and were awarded the [[Nobel Peace Prize]]. [[Aung San Suu Kyi]], [[José Ramos-Horta]], [[Kim Dae-jung]] and [[Shirin Ebadi]] were awarded the Rafto Prize prior to the [[Nobel Peace Prize]].{{cite web|url= http://humanrightshouse.org/Articles/5242.html|title= Rafto Foundation|publisher= Human Rights House Foundation|accessdate= November 1, 2017}} ==History== [[Thorolf Rafto]] was a professor of [[Economic History]] at the [[Norwegian School of Economics and Business Administration]] (NHH). He was also well known for his political activism in [[Eastern Europe]], especially in [[Hungary]], [[Czechoslovakia]] and [[Poland]]. During a visit to [[Prague]] in 1979 to hold a lecture for students excluded from universities for political reasons. Rafto was arrested and beaten by the communist security police which may have resulted in injuries which weakened his health. On 4 November 1986 Thorolf Rafto died.{{cite web|url=http://www.snl.no/.nbl_biografi/Thorolf_Rafto/utdypning|title=Thorolf Rafto|author=Arnljot Strømme Svendsen| publisher=Norsk biografisk leksikon|accessdate=21 September 2015}} His friends and colleagues agreed to establish a foundation that would continue Rafto's work such as promotion of freedom of speech and political expression in [[Eastern Europe]]. It was also decided to introduce a prize for human right activists. [[revolutions of 1989|The fall of the Iron Curtain]] and consequential democratization of Eastern European states led to a reconsideration the mission of the foundation. Meanwhile it had opened new possibilities to work with other geographical regions in a promotion of human rights. Already in 1990, the Rafto Prize was awarded to a [[Burma|Burmese]] democratic leader, [[Aung San Suu Kyi]] who, in the following year 1991, received the [[Nobel Peace Prize]] for her non-violent struggle for democracy and human rights. For the first years, the foundation was based at the [[Norwegian School of Economics and Business Administration]]. From 1997, the Rafto Foundation was relocated to the [[Human Rights House of Bergen]], Norway.{{cite web |url= http://humanrightshouse.org/Members/Norway___Bergen/Contact/index.html|title= HRH in Bergen, Norway|publisher= Human Rights House Foundation (HRHF)|accessdate= November 1, 2017}} ==Ceremony== The Rafto Prize is awarded annually on the first Sunday in November and since 1990, the official ceremony takes place at the [[Den Nationale Scene|National Theatre of Bergen]]. Among the invited guests are representatives from Bergen municipality and the Norwegian government, academics, supporters and partners of the Rafto Foundation and family members of the Rafto family.{{cite web|url= https://maritime-executive.com/features/the-rafto-legacy |title= The Rafto Legacy|publisher= The Maritime Executive |accessdate= November 1, 2017}} ==Criteria and nomination process== The annual deadline for nominations is 1 April. Voluntary organisations, institutions and individuals worldwide, with knowledge or interest in human rights are allowed to nominate candidates for the Rafto Prize. Former recipients of the prize can also nominate candidates, although candidates who are nominated by themselves or by their staff or by honorary officers will not be taken into consideration. After the deadline, all applications are carefully considered by the prize committee and the final decision is usually released at the press conference at Rafto House in September.{{cite web|url=http://www.rafto.org/?page=38|title=Home - Raftostiftelsen|publisher=|accessdate=21 September 2015}}{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} ==List of Laureates== {| align="center" class="wikitable sortable" |- ! {{expert needed|1=Canada|date=December 2011}}
'''[[Voter turnout in Canada]] is lowest for [[young voters]]'''.<ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Stolle | first1 = Dietlind | last2 = Hooghe | first2 = Marc | author-link1 = Dietlind Stolle | author-link2 = Marc Hooghe | title = The roots of social capital: attitudinal and network mechanisms in the relation between youth and adult indicators of social capital | journal = [[Acta Politica]] | volume = 39 | issue = 4 | pages = 422–441 | publisher = Palgrave Macmillan | doi = 10.1057/palgrave.ap.5500081 | date = December 2004 | url = https://dx.doi.org/10.1057/palgrave.ap.5500081 | ref = harv | postscript = .}}</ref> A general decline in electoral participation among the under-35 population has been observed in many democratic countries around the world, especially in Canada. "The youngest age cohort did experience a bump upwards in estimated voter turnout from 37% in the 2004 federal general election to 43.8% for the election that followed, before descending to 37.4% for the 2008 federal general election."<ref>[Alfred, Taiaiake., Pitawanakwat, Brook., and Price, Jackie. "The Meaning of Political Participation for Indigenous Youth: Charting the Course for Youth Civic and Political Participation." ''Canadian Policy Research Networks''. Jun 2007. Web. 25 Nov 2011. < www.cprn.ca/documents/48503_EN.pdf>]</ref> Participation in provincial elections for youth aged 18 to 24 was 28% in 2001. However, in the 2005 provincial election, the turnout in this age group increased to 35%.<ref>[Barnes, Andre. "Youth Voter Turnout in Canada: 1 Trends and Issues." Library of Parliament. 7 Apr 2010. Web. 11 Nov 2011. <http://www.parl.gc.ca/Content/LOP/ResearchPublications/2010-19-e.htm>]</ref> Evidently, low voter turnout of young Canadians has generated a great deal of concern.
"Detailed analyses of electoral participation since the 1968 federal election indicate that much of the decline has been driven by generational replacement."<ref>[Ibid.]</ref>
Indeed, the differences in electoral participation across age groups can be seen as a generation gap phenomenon. "The rate of voter participation declines steadily as one moves from the oldest to the youngest age cohorts." <ref>[Pammett, Jon H.. LeDuc, Lawrence. "Explaining the Turnout Decline in Canadian Federal Elections: A New Survey of Non-voters." ''Elections Canada''. Mar 2003. Web. Oct 2011 <www.elections.ca>]</ref> The study by Jon H. Pammett and Lawrence LeDuc employed by [[Elections Canada]] reveals just how large the gap between the youngest and oldest voters has become.<ref>[Ibid.]</ref> One explanation for this phenomenon is that one's age can affect one's view as to the relevance of the issues that typically dominate the political agenda.<ref>[Gidengil, Elizabeth. , Blais, Andre. , Everitt, Joanna., Fournier, Patrick., and Nevitte, Neil. "Missing the Message Young Adults and the Election Issues." ''Elections Canada''. Web. 18 Nov 2011. <http://www.elections.ca/res/eim/article_search/article.asp?id=122&lang=e&frmPageSize=>]</ref> The trend analysis demonstrates that the generation gap applies to specific political issues. "Views on school integration proved the exception to the rule, an exception that is explicable in terms of massive period effects and possibly life-cycle effects operating on the young."<ref>[Jennings, M. Kent, and Niemi, Richard G. ''Generations and Politics: A Panel Study of Young Adults and Their Parents.'' New Jersey: Princeton University Press, 1981. Pg. 161.]</ref>
The proportion of Canadians under 15 years of age dropped from 32.5% in 1941 to 17.6% in 2006.<ref>[Heard, Andrew. "Historical Voter Turnout in Canada Federal Elections & Referenda, 1867-2008." ''Elections''. Web. 04 Nov. 2011. <https://www.sfu.ca/~aheard/elections/historical-turnout.html>]</ref> In 2015, a statistical milestone was reached, in which the proportion of Canadians over 64 (5.78 million) topped the proportion of those under 15 (5.75 million),[https://www.thestar.com/news/canada/2015/09/29/more-canadians-over-64-than-under-15-statscan-reports.html as reported by the Star.]
Younger Canadians tend to be less interested in politics: Only one in 20 Canadians between 18 and 30 years of age (in 2000) had ever belonged to a political party, compared with one-third of those over age 60.<ref>[ Mackinnon, Mary Pat. , Pitre, Sonia. , and Watling Judy. [http://www.cprn.ca/documents/48800_FR.pdf "Lost in Translation: (Mis) Understanding Youth Engagement: Synthesis Report."] ''Canadian Policy Research Networks''. Oct 2007. Web. 26 Nov 2011.</ref> There is concern whether a failure to engage younger Canadians early will have a detrimental effect on our democracy over time. "There is no question that over the past two decades, we have seen youth voting rates declining at a precipitous rate to the point where clear majorities of the younger generations don't vote and may well never do so."<ref>[Graves, Frank. "The Looming Legitimacy Crisis: Time to Take the Discretionary out of Democracy?" ''Ekos Politics''. 21 Oct 2011. Web. 22 Nov 2011. < http://www.ekospolitics.com/index.php/2011/10/the-looming-legitimacy-crisis-october-21-2011/>]</ref>
== Young voter turnout factors ==
We might wonder why the youth are not very interested in more traditional types of political participation. Stephen P. Nicholson uses Ricker's suggestion that the outcome of a vote may depend on the agenda.<ref>[Nicholson, Stephen P. Voting The Agenda: Candidates, Elections, And Ballot Propositions. Princeton; Oxford: Princeton University Press, 2005.]</ref> What type of agenda settings are shaping young Canadians? What is the trend in youth civic and political engagement in Canada? To what degree do political activities influence young Canadian voters? How do social differences influence the structure of society? An analysis of basic theoretical reasons behind the low voter turnout of young Canadians was done based on quantitative and qualitative research. The analysis reported some factors that contributed to the unwillingness of youth to vote and to participate in democracy: 1. Social Factors, different implications of youth values from older generation.<ref>[Mackinnon, Mary Pat. , Pitre, Sonia. , and Watling Judy. "Lost in Translation: (Mis) Understanding Youth Engagement: Synthesis Report." Canadian Policy Research Networks. Oct 2007. Web. 26 Nov 2011. < www.cprn.ca/documents/48800_FR.pdf>]</ref> 2. Institutional Factor, differences in Political discourses. It will highlight demographic trends in Canada and have created this new fixation on age as a major determinant of political participation and public policy.<ref>[MacManus, Susan A. Young Vs. Old: Generational Combat in the 21st Century.Colorado; Oxford: Westview Press, Inc., A Division of HarperCollins Publishers, Inc., 1996. P. 4.]</ref> Also, what is the role of newspaper to engage with the young voters? There is no particular reason to attribute low voter turnout to any one factor, though some factors may be more important than others.<ref>[Pammett, Jon. H., and LeDuc, Lawrence. "Explaining the Turnout Decline in Canadian Federal Elections: A New Survey of Non-voters." Elections Canada. Carleton; Toronto: Mar 2003. Web. 14 Oct 2011. <www.elections.ca> P. 8]</ref>
==The assessment of political activity== [[File:YouthVoteInCanada poster KensingtonMarket October2015.jpg|thumb|Poster in a shop window in Kensington Market, Toronto, October 2015, during the federal election campaign. It contains the words of political commentator of Rick Mercer.]]Canadian electoral participants attribute "turnout decline to negative public attitudes toward the performance of the politicians and political institutions involved in federal politics."<ref>[Ibid. P. 7 ]</ref> "When it came to the question of asking whether politics is a way for the powerful to themselves or, instead, a way for the less powerful to compete on equal footing, more respondents in both countries chose the cynical view." <ref>[Milner, Henry. "Political Knowledge and Participation Among Young Canadians and Americans" Institute for Research on Public Policy. Nov 2007. Web. 11 Nov 2011. < www.irpp.org/wp/archive/wp2007-01.pdf>]</ref> A survey done across the nation shows a clear plurality: 49% disapprove of the way [[Stephen Harper]], Prime Minister and leader of Conservative Party of Canada, is handling his job compared to [[Barack Obama]], President of The United States, whose disapproval rate is 12%.<ref>["Election Anyone?: Speaker's Ruling May Not Tempt Any Party To Force An Election." ''Ekos Politics''. 29 Apr 2010. Web. 04 Nov 2011. P. 13 <http://www.ekospolitics.com/index.php/2010/04/election-anyone-april-29-2010/ >]</ref> Since voting is evidently central to citizens' politics in representative democracies, it is unsurprising that young participants' attitudes to politics were partly shaped by their perceptions of their position in relation to this most basic of political citizenship rights. Indeed, Synthesis Report by Canadian Policy Research Networks reports that youths do not tend to connect the role of government with the issues they think are important.<ref>[Mackinnon, Mary Pat. , Pitre, Sonia. , and Watling Judy. "Lost in Translation: (Mis) Understanding Youth Engagement: Synthesis Report." ''Canadian Policy Research Networks''. Oct 2007. Web. 26 Nov 2011. < www.cprn.ca/documents/48800_FR.pdf>]</ref>
=== The changing style of political discourse ===
There are roughly four times as many votes registered by seniors than by younger voters. This effect is compounded by dramatic differences in political preferences with seniors being more than twice as likely to favour conservative choices than younger voters. "In a decade or two, the younger voters will be in the prime of their lives and paying for the political choices of their now departed grandparents which are not likely to reflect the priorities or, one could speculate, the needs of next Canada."<ref>[Graves, Frank. "The Looming Legitimacy Crisis: Time to Take the Discretionary out of Democracy?" ''Ekos Politics''. 21 Oct 2011. Web. 22 Nov 2011. P.2. < http://www.ekospolitics.com/index.php/2011/10/the-looming-legitimacy-crisis-october-21-2011/>]</ref> In other words, this phenomenon is age-related, as there are variations in the personal relevance of the issues that typically dominate the political discourse.<ref>[ Gidengil, Elizabeth. , Blais, Andre. , Everitt, Joanna., Fournier, Patrick., and Nevitte, Neil. "Missing the Message Young Adults and the Election Issues." ''Elections Canada''. Web. 18 Nov 2011. <http://www.elections.ca/res/eim/article_search/article.asp?id=122&lang=e&frmPageSize=>]</ref> Disengagement from the political agenda setting becomes significant as the age of our population rises, but their relative clout has been dramatically magnified by the declining voting rates of younger citizens. The commentary on youth disengagement suggests that "young Canadians are turned off by electoral politics because party platforms and party leaders pay too little attention to the issues that really concerned younger citizens."<ref>[Ibid. P.3.]</ref> Nanos Research conducted a survey for individuals aged 18 years or older between August 13 and September 30, 2011, to question, "What is your most important PROVINCIAL issue of concern?" And the research data identifies they mostly concern the health 26.4% from February 2010, 23.2%.<ref>[Nano, John. "What is your most important PROVINCIAL issue of concern?" ''Nanos Research''. 01 Oct 2011. Web. 05 Oct 2011. <http://www.nanosresearch.com/library/opinion.html>]</ref> And only 16% of those named job/economy as their second most important.<ref>[Ibid.]</ref> The number one issue for young Canadians was health. Another survey was conducted by Elections Canada to pinpoint the most important issue in the election and Canadians aged 18 to over 60 were asked to select the issue that was most important to them personally.<ref>[Gidengil, Elizabeth. , Blais, Andre. , Everitt, Joanna., Fournier, Patrick., and Nevitte, Neil. "Missing the Message Young Adults and the Election Issues." ''Elections Canada''. Web. 18 Nov 2011. P.3. <http://www.elections.ca/res/eim/article_search/article.asp?id=122&lang=e&frmPageSize=>]</ref> One of the common issues was health. Indeed, a striking finding from the survey data is how similar the priorities of Canadians are, regardless of their age. Evidently, [[Ekos Politics]] constructed a survey in October 2010 that asked which party you would vote for if a federal election were held tomorrow. The result of Ontario vote intention was [[Progressive Conservative Party of Canada|Progressive Conservative]] Party 36.0% and Liberal 34.2% second.<ref>[Election Anyone?: Speaker's Ruling May Not Tempt Any Party To Force An Election." ''Ekos Politics''. 29 Apr 2010. Web. 04 Nov 2011. P. 9. <http://www.ekospolitics.com/index.php/2010/04/election-anyone-april-29-2010/ >]</ref> However, a year later, the new data justified an adjustment in Ontario 2011 Election from PC 34.0% to [[Liberal Party of Canada|Liberal]] 38.6% since the 2010 elections.<ref>["EKOS' Final Poll For The 2011 Ontario Election: …And A Few Comment On Why This Isn't Our Most Important Poll." ''Ekos Politics''. 05 Oct 2011. Web. 11 Nov 2011. <http://www.ekospolitics.com/index.php/2011/10/ekos%e2%80%99-final-poll-for-the-2011-ontario-election-october-5-2011/>]</ref> According to ''Ekos Politics'', they predicted, "a Liberal majority government, though we observed a last-minute shift to the Progressive Conservative Party, and cautioned that the final outcome was far from certain."<ref>["A Brief Post Mortem on Polling During the Ontario 2011 Election." ''Ekos Politics''. 07 Oct 2011. Web. 14 Nov 2011. <http://www.ekospolitics.com/index.php/2011/10/a-brief-post-mortem-on-polling-during-the-ontario-2011-election-october-7-2011/>]</ref> The end result of the Ontario election evaluates the notion that people's involvement in alternative political behaviour is central to assessing their level of political interest.<ref>[Milan, Anne. "Willing to participate: Political engagement of young adults." ''Statistics Canada.'' 2005. Web. 28 Oct 2011. P. 3. < www.statcan.gc.ca/kits-trousses/pdf/social/edu04_0155a-eng.pdf>]</ref>
=== Political knowledge and trust ===
"Political knowledge is a democratic value. It is also an important ingredient in democratic citizenship, influencing public attitudes and opinions and, thus political behaviour."<ref>Milner, Henry.[http://www.irpp.org/wp/archive/wp2007-01.pdf "Political Knowledge and Participation Among Young Canadians and Americans"], [[Institute for Research on Public Policy]]. Nov 2007. Web. 11 Nov 2011.</ref> Young Canadians display a pattern of civic and political engagement that differentiates them from other aged groups. According to Henry Milner, the political knowledge centralizes to the young voter decline.<ref>[Ibid]</ref> Brenda O'Neil supports Milner's analysis by saying, "counterintuitively, cynicism toward government and the political system is generally lower among young Canadians than among older ones, and have greater confidence in party leaders and candidates than older generations.<ref>O'Neil, Brenda. [http://www.cprn.ca/documents/48800_FR.pdf "Indifferent or Just Different? The Political and Civic Engagement of Young People in Canada: Charting the Course for Youth Civic and Political Participation."], ''[[Canadian Policy Research Networks]]''. Jun 2007. Web. 31 Oct 2011.</ref> Both Milner and O'Neil argue young voter participants have a strong engagement towards the effects on political knowledge. "Voters' lack of political information raises important concerns about contemporary democratic practices."<ref name=WhoLearns>Nadeau, Richard., Nevitte, Neil., Gidengil, Elisabeth., and Blais, Andre.[http://ces-eec.org/pdf/UPCP_A_319893_O.pdf ''"Election Campaigns as Information Campaigns: Who Learns What and Does it Matter?"''], [[Routledge Taylor & Francis Group]]. Web. 10 Nov 2011</ref> A non-voting or alternative activity "can be a valuable source of political education [which develops] politically relevant knowledge, awareness, understanding and skills."<ref>Milan, Anne. [http://www.statcan.gc.ca/kits-trousses/pdf/social/edu04_0155a-eng.pdf "Willing to participate: Political engagement of young adults."] ''[[Statistics Canada]]''. 2005. Web. 28 Oct 2011.
